story:
Short Summary

Projeto Educação e Água is a short documentary about the work that the Project WET Foundation is doing to improve health in some of Rio de Janeiro's poorest neighborhoods through water education and advocacy. This film follows Project WET, a U.S. nonprofit organization with a 20-year history of creating and implementing water education activities around the world, as they partner with local organizations and community leaders to create behavior change that will reduce disease, improve trash management, and maintain clean water sources. The film will explore the challenges facing these communities and improvements they have already made. 

This film aims to help Project WET expand their programs through education and awareness. 

This spring, filmmaker Maureen Lee Maloney will be traveling to Rio for 3 weeks with Julia Nelson, Program Manager for Project WET. She has been working within Rio's slums, known as favelas, since 2012. 

In the past, these neighborhoods were ignored by the government. They completely lacked any kind of infrastructure, including garbage removal and water treatment. Since 2010 the government of Brazil has taken steps to incorporate these areas into the city and improve the lives of the people there. However, with so many years of neglect to overcome, progress has been slow

When Project WET first began working with these communities they found high levels of dengue fever and diarrhea, both serious diseases that are closely linked to polluted water sources. Often children play in trash, and less than 40% of school children were washing their hands after using the toilet. Project WET has already collaborated with local partners to create customized educational materials focused on improving the hygiene and sanitation behaviors of children in favela communities.

The next step for Project WET is to train local educators to use the hands-on methodology and activities in the newly customized educators guide. These educators will then become Project WET Trainers and will train other educators in their communities. The goal is to train at least 500 educators in Rio de Janeiro, reaching at least 10,000 children and their families. 

Access to clean water is critically important. What can you do today to ensure clean water for future generations?

What We Need & What You Get

With only $4500 we can afford to produce and distribute a 20-minute documentary about how Project WET's educational program is improving health in Rio de Janeiro, demonstrating the power of education in addressing serious water-related health threats. This total includes all pre-production (research & planning), production (travel, equipment, crew), and post-production (editing) costs.


There are special discounts for people who join the campaign during the first week, so don't miss out!

We want you to get something cool in exchange for your support. There are environmental education materials, a special Collector's Edition DVD, and beautiful photos of Rio by Maureen Lee Maloney.

The Impact

Small organizations like Project WET are able to have a much bigger impact than large organizations because they work one-on-one with people in the communities they serve. However, they often don't have the resources to educate the public about their work. A documentary will be a valuable tool to support the programs provided by Project WET by raising awareness and increasing understanding of their programs.

Find out more about Projeto Educação e Água  

Other Ways You Can Help

Telling your friends and family about this project is FREE and it is a HUGE HELP! Thanks for using the Share This links to post this project to your Facebook or Twitter pages.

Children playing near trash-filled canals.


A cleaner Rio through recycling.

story:
About the Phoenix Project
A Market-driven Sustainable Cleanup Solution

A carbon-negative, scalable, and sustainable oil cleanup model and reclamation process enabling the development of sustainable Enterprise Recovery & Empowerment Zones .


Reconnaissance Mission Crowd Funding Campaign
From Wayne King, Team Leader

Of all the things I have been fortunate enough to do in my life: Guiding in the White Mountains for Mowglis, School of the Open,  Serving as a Senator in the New Hampshire Senate, Democratic Nominee for Governor of New Hampshire, Publisher of a magazine and CEO of a public company; the work I have done in West Africa is among the most gratifying.

I have been going to West Africa since I first took a team of people there on behalf of the Ford Foundation in 1997. Since that time the team has broadened to include people on both continents and many companies and organizations that enthusiastically have joined together with us.

For more than four years we have been working on the ideas and technology behind the Phoenix Project. 

It began simply as a determination to clean up oil spills in the Niger Delta. Spills that were being ignored. The problem in the Niger Delta is huge.



But as we began to explore the ways of dealing with the oil spills we realized that with the right technologies and a determination to use the resources required for the cleanup to do MORE than just clean up the spill - we could do something extraordinary. 

We could create a Phoenix Effect . . .

This is the term we use to describe a powerful multi-dimensional outcome with a broad-based solution to a problem that traditionally sees only one dimensional approaches. Creating a beautiful flowering of positive outcomes . . . a renaissance, a rebirth that touches us in many ways. 

In  our specific case, we could create an “Enterprise Recovery and Empowerment Zone” using the clean up process to create both a cleaner environment and an enterprise community built around it.

Better still, we could do this in a way that would be sustainable, replicable, carbon negative and (hopefully) profitable enough to leave the community with a source of electricity before moving on to the next Zone repeating the process again.

Just imagine  . . . We identify the Zone for cleanup. Keeping in mind that our goals for the future include not only a rebirth of the land but an economic renaissance for the region.

We use sustainable technologies to clean up the oil, recovering and recycling as much of the oil spilled as possible and recover and recycle the oil.



From the biomass created during the cleanup, we create electricity for communities that may never have had access to reliable and affordable electricity - employing a new Thermal Recovery technology - gassifying the biomass - in a green pyrolysis plant;

The pyrolysis plant is mobile and small enough to fit on a trailer truck bed. It is a closed system plant for cleanly and sustainably processing the biomass, producing electricity and biochar.


Biochar is a powerful soil amendment (fertilizer) that has been demonstrated to enhance agricultural productivity by as much as 400%. Biochar is also a carbon sink that captures and stores carbon - making the entire process CARBON NEGATIVE; 

Biochar can be employed to help restore the lands being cleaned up and also sold to support the other activities of the Enterprise and Empowerment Zone. Furthermore, it appears that biochar production and usage will qualify under the Kyoto protocols for the sale of green energy credits.

In addition to all this, we create entrepreneurial and research opportunities in Agriculture, oil spill remediation; climate change remediation, bio-fuel production and electricity generation and probably dozens of other ideas that we have not yet thought of yet!

All of this yields a model that we will share openly with the world. A sustainable open source solution to oil spill pollution.

While this crowd funding campaign is aimed at raising the seed funding for the reconnaissance mission to identify the Zone, meet with the key constituencies and craft agreements, we want to share the details for the entire project that we have painstakingly developed over the last four years.  

We want to do this for several reasons: So that you understand the vision and the technology as completely as you wish to.  Our transparency and your confidence in our work will, we believe, spur you to make every effort to help us spread the word, to help us raise the revenues and to generate new ideas for research and entrepreneurial projects that could grow from these efforts.

Every dollar, euro, yen, uwan, nira, pound raised will be used to make this powerful idea a reality. Any funds raised beyond those needed for seeding the Phoenix Project will go directly toward covering the balance we need to raise to complete the project - especially covering the cost of the power plant which we hope to be able to gift to the community to act as the critical mass for the future operations of the Enterprise and Empowerment Zone.

The Crowd Funding campaign to seed the project hopes to raise $85,000. These funds will be used to cover costs of bringing together all of the  stakeholders and the expertise needed to move forward; identifying the area to establish the Zone; creating the legal agreements necessary for moving ahead; 

Because the Niger Delta is a dangerous place, security costs play a fairly significant role in the cost of the reconnaissance mission. The recon mission will bring the team together with community leaders, government officials and oil company representatives to select the area that will be designated as the first Enterprise and Empowerment Zone. We will be issuing a paper during the first week of the crowd funding campaign that will describe, in detail, the process of site selection.

While we hope that you will want to donate and share information about the Phoenix Project with your family, friends and social networks because the people of the Niger Delta deserve better than they have gotten, we have some amazing perks nonetheless including one of a kind bracelets, necklaces and earrings crafted from West African gemstones and baubles by Loba, an artist who creates sustainable artwork she calls gemstone finery and beaded frippery.

No Food For Lazy Man - a sustainable drum maker in Accra will be creating Djembe drums and a number of limited edition posters and fine art prints are also among the cool perks.

When this portion of the Phoenix Project is complete, we hope to have identified a site for the first Enterprise and recovery zone; 

We plan to make this project work no matter what it takes so if we don't reach our goal we will still continue to move forward. But we believe that this idea will catch fire because it is both replicable and sustainable and offers an opportunity to test a concept that could have world wide implications for oil spill cleanup, poverty alleviation and community economic development.

Read the comprehensive Concept Paper for the Phoenix Project here.

How can I Help?

  1. Like us on Facebook (facebook.com/NigerDeltaPhoenix) and Twitter (@Save_NigerDelta ) so you are up to date on every new development.
  2. Join us by signing up for our Blog  bit.ly/DeltaPhoenix it will help keep you in tough with our efforts.
  3. If you know anyone with connections to Chevron, Shell, Mobile/Exxon or any other oil company send them an invitation to view the campaign and contact us directly. We have all the usual contact information and we are working on developing the relationships, but sometime a personal connection makes all the difference. Sometimes it can help leapfrog the usual efforts.
  4. If you would like to volunteer in some capacity, email us at NigerDeltaPhoenix@gmail.com;
  5. If you have ideas for us, we would love to hear about them. email us or participate in one of the upcoming Google Meet Up conferences that we will be having In the coming weeks.
  6. Please use the hashtag #PhoenixProjectNigerDelta to help us build momentum.

About our Perks

Equivalent Offsets and Cool Perquisites (Perks)

Many companies have explored the option of purchasing offsets to ameliorate or “Offset” their carbon consumption. 

In this case we have devised our donation methodology and explanation of benefits and perquisites (Perks) in a way that recognizes the fact that each of us, no matter how conscientious we are about our consumption, plays a role in the pressure that has created the environmental woes of the Niger Delta and that the Phoenix Project- Niger Delta’s Enterprise Zone, when operational, will be generating electricity for the community and creating jobs, generating wealth AND creating a CARBON-NEGATIVE environment. While we are NOT providing offsets that would meet the rigorous standards of an offset audit, we are providing “peace-of-mind” or "ethical" offsets. We are simply trying to get you to understand that your actions will in fact ethically-offset your consumption!

Some folks have asked us why we are doing this in an area as dangerous as the Niger Delta. The answer in short is that the Niger Delta is where it is needed most and we refuse to allow terrorists or profit-crazy oil companies to prevent us from moving forward with this important mission.

We have some very cool perks to offer, but the most important thing that you will receive is the pride associated with playing your part in helping to launch an effort that will not only clean up oil spills in the Niger Delta but use the profits generated by the cleanup to create good jobs, generate wealth and entrepreneurial opportunity for young people; and, opportunities that will empower women and men in the Niger Delta.

Every dollar that we raise over and above our target for the reconnaissance mission will go directly toward the full development of the first Enterprise Recovery and EmpowermentZone.

Our Perks

#1 The Nigerian Danfo Ride or Lawnmower Fill Offset 

$1- $10.00 USD or equivalent 
You’re a member of the Team!

Catching a ride on a Danfo (above) or filling your lawnmower will run you somewhere in this price range. If you’ve done either of these things in the last year, you can offset the carbon by donating a like amount to the Phoenix Project - Niger Delta.

Perk: We’ll thank you by listing your name on our “Heroes Wall” on the Phoenix Project Blog. 

#2 The Taxi Ride or 10 6-packs of soda

$11 - 50.00 

If you took a Taxi in New York City recently you paid more than $11 just to get into the taxi, but in most of the rest of the world this is the range of a standard Taxi ride. 

The soda may surprise you. Every time you drink a soda in a plastic bottle, 1/3 of the volume of that soda was required in oil to manufacture the bottle.

In either case, your generous commitment of $11-50 will offset that taxi ride or those sodas and will get us farther down the road toward a day when we can make the process for establishing the Enterprise zone open source information allowing any community with an oil spill to do it themselves if they choose.

Perk: We’ll send you a thank you email and proudly display your name and residence on a plaque at the Enterprise Zone. Permanently enshrining your place in this historic effort.

#3 The Fill Up "Offset"

$51 - $100.00

Whether you drive a hybrid or an SUV filling your vehicle just one time is going to run you somewhere in this price range. If you are in the US, chances are that the gasoline comes from one of the 543,000 barrels a day of oil imported into the US from Nigeria - almost all of it from the Niger Delta. If you are in Europe, Nigeria is the 5th largest supplier - but the situation in Ukraine likely will have an impact on this perhaps moving Nigeria to a higher level.. 

The Perk

Best Friend’s Dreams LImited Edition Poster

16” x 22” Limited Edition, Digitally signed, poster by renowned artist and team leader Wayne King. Features the following quote: “A friend is someone who knows the song in your heart and sings it back to you when you have forgotten how it goes.”


#4  Filling The Generator or a Month of Commuting

$100 - $200 USD or equivalent

If you have a generator that needs filling, or if you commute to work and wanted a  Peace-of-Mind offset of the carbon for either of these items the cost will be somewhere in this range. 

Perk: Project Phoenix T Shirt: We’ll thank you for your contribution at this level with a Project Phoenix T-Shirt.



#5 Offset A Month of Gas Fills or  Heating Oil Fillup

$201 - 500 USD or equivalent

If you are not doing long distance driving and you are careful about heating your home, the cost associated with this equivalent offset is probably close to what you spend for gas or to fill a heating oil tank.  Your generous contribution to the Phoenix Project at this level will yield peace of mind that you have taken an action that will offset well over the equivalent value of carbon with your contribution.

Perk: We will thank you with a beautiful signed fine art print  of a young man looking to the sea entitled: “To Dream”  from a special limited edition of only 100 (12” x 16”)  prints. This is a fine art Giclee print using archival inks on 100% rag fine art paper signed by the artist and numbered. 


#6 The Semi-Truck Fillup or Airfare "Offset"

$501 - $999

Whether you drive a truck and have had to fill up your semi, or shipped something with a truck recently or took a flight, you consumed a lot of fuel. Your donation will provide a "Peace-of-Mind" offset of that consumption, bringing the day closer when Carbon Negative energy will be produced in the Niger Delta, driving economic growth, jobs and a cleaner environment.

Perk: “Sustainable Gemstone Finery and beaded Frippery by Loba”. Choose between ear rings, bracelets and necklaces created especially for the Phoenix Project by the artist Loba (. . .just Loba, like Cher). One-of-a-kind beautiful jewelry incorporating beads and frippery from West Africa as well as other green gemstone finery and frippery. When you make your contribution we will send you a page of selections from which to make your choice. 


Alternative Perk
Limited Edition Fine Art Print
At the Water’s Edge

From a limited edition of 10 prints signed, numbered and with a certificate of authenticity from the artist, Wayne D. King.


#7  "Offset" One year of Gasoline or Heating Oil

$1,000 - $5,000 USD or equivalent

Perk: A Djembe Drum from No Food For Lazy Man. No Food for Lazy Man is a sustainable drum making company in Accra, Ghana. owner Kennedy Opayeki  (left) has agreed to provide a standard size Djembe to anyone who makes a commitment of 1000 or more to the Phoenix Project.


#8 "Offset" your Life for a Year 

$50,000 or more - You are our Hero!

You are on our team and we are your team for a one Man/Woman Trade Mission. 

For a donation of $50,000 or more we will make you an official member of our team for one trip to Nigeria. We will also provide support to you if you wish to explore the options for other entrepreneurial opportunities in Nigeria while you are in the country. We will help set up meetings with government officials and other business people and provide you with the support you need for 2 days.

We supply security, housing, food, and (coach) airfare to and from Nigeria. You take care of visas, shots, insurance etc and any in-country expenses associated with your trade mission. Plus! You get to join us for a visit to the facility in the Niger Delta sometime in the next 48 months.

If you wish to come with a larger delegation, please contact us and we can work out the details for a bigger delegation.

Choose between ear rings, bracelets and necklaces created especially for the Phoenix Project by the artist Loba (. . .just Loba, like Cher). One-of-a-kind beautiful jewelry incorporating beads and frippery from West Africa as well as other green gemstone finery and frippery. When you make your contribution we will send you a page of selections from which to make your choice. 



Alternative PerkLimited Edition Fine Art PrintAt the Water’s Edge
From a limited edition of 10 prints signed, numbered and with a certificate of authenticity from the artist, Wayne D. King.


#7  "Offset" One year of Gasoline or Heating Oil

$1,000 - $5,000 USD or equivalent


Perk: A Djembe Drum from No Food For Lazy Man. No Food for Lazy Man is a sustainable drum making company in Accra, Ghana. owner Kennedy Opayeki  (left) has agreed to provide a standard size Djembe to anyone who makes a commitment of 1000 or more to the Phoenix Project.

















































#8 "Offset" your Life for a Year 
$50,000 or more - You are our Hero!

You are on our team and we are your team for a one Man/Woman Trade Mission. 
For a donation of $50,000 or more we will make you an official member of our team for one trip to Nigeria. We will also provide support to you if you wish to explore the options for other entrepreneurial opportunities in Nigeria while you are in the country. We will help set up meetings with government officials and other business people and provide you with the support you need for 2 days.


We supply security, housing, food, and (coach) airfare to and from Nigeria. You take care of visas, shots, insurance etc and any in-country expenses associated with your trade mission. Plus! You get to join us for a visit to the facility in the Niger Delta sometime in the next 48 months.


If you wish to come with a larger delegation, please contact us and we can work out the details for a bigger delegation.

story:
Project Description:

    We only have a few days to go, and are still a good way away from our goal, but don't let that keep you from reading on.  It may take us a little longer before everything develops to the full scope we imagine, but your contributions can still manifest a solar shower, rain water cistern, tea house garden, or some swings for the Kids' Camp!

Imagine this;

    5 groups of 20 people, stationed throughout an ever expanding festival grounds, learning permaculture concepts, natural building techniques, and healthy living skills, in a festive environment.  Imagine you are there, listening to the minstrels as they tickle the work teams with rhythmic background music.  Suddenly hunger strikes.  You walk to a tree, pick a tropical fruit, & relish in the juicy goodness of the moment. In the evenings, you gather by a forest-clad stage, for a variety of entertainment and dancing, and close the nights with drums and singing by the fire.  Imagine that this gathering is inexpensive, family friendly, and could grow into a more than annual event.  Imagine that you were one of the special people that helped it become a more enchanting, playful, and delicious reality!


  Welcome to Earthworks!  We are actively creating a living edible festival grounds for people to come together and celebrate creativity, sustainable living, healing, arts, whole foods, music and more.  The location of these festivals is Finca Fruición, a permaculture-based land cooperative in the southern pacific zone of Costa Rica.  We are raising money specifically to build rain shelters for the workshop zones, children’s Creation Station, dance floor, stage and fire circle, as well as a self-serve kitchen for festival goers to prepare their own food or food that they can purchase from the event's local farmer's market.   We will also be building rainwater cisterns for solar showers and other washing and irrigating needs.

    The area already has many fruit trees, and is designed as a model food forest/festival grounds, where people can celebrate together while harvesting the abundance of the land.  The structures are all flowing, organic feeling open-air spaces where people can have fun and be protected from the elements. Another exciting feature is that not only will children be welcome, but they will almost have their own mini-festival within the festival!


List of monetary needs:

- A recycling station to put up in a couple of our neighboring villages, to divert their trash, make recycling easy for them, and gather great supplies for some of the wonderfully creative alternative building projects that we have in store.

- An amazing children's Creation Station!

- Workshop space/yoga deck

- Covered stage and dance floor

- Fire circle sky lodge

- More composting toilets (we already have a few)

- Rainwater catchment for solar showers

- Edible plants throughout the festival grounds such as raspberries for boarders, gooseberries, cherry tomatoes, custard apple, rose apple, chayote, bananas, cacao, ice cream beans and many more.

- Shovels, picks, tamping rods, and other needed tools to keep the troops busy.

- Videography

- All the sweet gifts that we get to mail out to you and the rest of our amazing supporters!


  This is just the start.  With this base infrastructure set, we will begin the hosting of a series of annual week-long Eco-Festivals, changing the way our culture experiences music festivals.  The great thing about this festival is that it will get more and more magical, year after year, as the participants make personal and group contributions to the space for future attendants to come!  The eventuality of the festival is to plant-up and develop the festival grounds, in the first couple years, to the point where the attendants are comfortably enjoying their self-made solar hot showers, communal kitchen, composting toilets, tiki torch lit pathways, and a host of other fun and beautiful enhancements to the park, and from there, begin traveling outside of the park to the local school, community center, etc.  While we will be doing at least one outreach project per event, to begin with, we anticipate establishing a stable, self-maintaining, edible hosting grounds, from which the majority of the projects will then turn to benefit the surrounding villages in our area.

  If you’ve traveled Central America, you probably know that bananas, cows and coffee have become the predominant income source for many farmers in many regions, which has significantly impacted Costa Rica’s otherwise rich bio-diversity.  Earthworks festival grounds and host farm are already a rich sanctuary for flora and fauna, and it is one of the festival’s chief aims to re-seed the region’s biodiversity and regenerate its precious biological corridors.  We have already established a working relationship with Community Carbon Trees Costa Rica who will be aiding our efforts with generous donations of native and fruiting trees to use in the regeneration and reforestation outreach projects to come.


  And none of this will be possible without a good dose of FUN!  Focusing on local bands, children's theater, skill toy/flow art classes, group participation park-wide games, costumery, tomfoolery and other random antics, the spirit of Make Believe will be crucial to the health generating focus of the event.  And on that tip, organic food, healing arts, and self-care will be among the highlighted overtones of how we do business.

  We have already invested significant funds into preparing the space for lovely smaller-scale test events that we’ve held over the past few years, and we have good perspective for what more it needs to host a larger and longer celebration.  We have dozens of mature trees already planted throughout the zone, as well as the beginnings of the kids' play tower, trampoline, and more!

  Financial sustainability is an important factor for us in putting on these events and inviting others to participate.  With the ticket sales, our aim is to be able to pay the workshop coordinators, playshop instructors, Creation Station Chiefs, bands and other devoted folks, as well as buy materials, etc.  With your donations we won’t have to struggle, hoping that we break even to cover the infrastructure costs, and simply give thanks to everyone for participating in the festival.  What’s more, if we achieve our goal, we will also be free to donate 12% of all the festival’s proceeds to assist with additional local school and village programs!

With your contributions, this can be a rewarding, fun, and far less stressful success for everyone involved!

   Whether you can give a dollar, 5, 25, or 500, PLEASE share this campaign with your network.  We are asking for a base amount to set the stage for the first events, but with additional funding there is no limit as to how amazing and far reaching a reality this can become, nor to the amount of people that we can share it with and influence!  In the end, we are aiming to create a new template for festivals that can be reseeded throughout the country and, eventually, abroad as well.  The power we have when we come together in a spirit of harmony is tremendous.  Both this festival and this campaign are testaments to that reality. 

Together, we WILL change the world!.  In fact, we already are…
Again, we thank you dearly for your support!

The Fruition Center for Holistic Ecology

*We will begin arranging the dates, for the Earthworks Festival 2014, after this crowd funding campaign is completed.  If you are interested in being a part of the EarthWorks production team, please contact us at FruitionCenter@gmail.com for more details.

Sign up to our newsletter and keep up with project's progress!
For your support, we'll also send you 4 Permaculture in Action Articles.



Make sure to check our Updates and the Gallery Page of this campaign to see more great videos that have been filmed here at Finca Fruición.


More news!  We have just confirmed the dates of our next festival, as well as commitment from two of our rocket stove workshop leaders!

Put it on your calendar, January 10th-14th will host our next event under the new name Intégrate.  Intégrate is a term in spanish that means "integrate yourself", that we feel encapsulates the heart of what we want to offer in these gatherings.

story:
Power Station - A power station (also referred to as a generating station, power plant, powerhouse or generating plant) is an industrial facility for the generation of electric power. (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_station)



What is iPower Station?

It’s independence. It’s energy security. It’s power freedom when and where you need it.

iPower Station is modular, portable and practical solar power. It smartly combines energy generation, electric storage, and electric supply into a useful mobile power plant. And best of all, it’s open source too.

Many others have tried to build a “utility in a box” prototype - without success. Or they attempt “lock-in” with non-standard components in their proprietary units. Still others over promise with slick marketing - unnecessarily making people overpay for solar.

As military veterans always paying attention to detail, we weren’t impressed. And we decided to do something about it.  iPower Station is NOT a prototype. With more than 3 years invested in design and development, we pay careful attention to details that matter most, including:

1. Proven Technology. Every iPower Station utilizes technology that’s been field proven for over a decade.

2. Quality Components. Every iPower Station is built of high quality components, ensuring decades of reliable power.

3. Insanely Great Design. Designing the iPower Station drove us insane at times, but paid off in the “4 Big Easy”:

  • Easy to set up. Less than a minute to set up and produce power.
  • Easy to use. Completely “plug-n-play” with everything within easy reach and sight.
  • Easy to maintain. Stores and transports easily. Almost maintenance free.
  • Easy to expand. Want more power generation or storage? Just plug it in and go!

Power appliances, lights, computers, tablets, smart phones, tools, and much, much more. Ready for emergency power, tailgate parties, camping, farm markets or Burning Man. There are hundreds of uses.

iPower Station is the answer when you ask, “What can iPower?”


Round One Mission

We need your help. Funds from this campaign are applied to multiple purposes, in this order:

  • Solar for Sandy - New Jersey (see details below)
  • Legal stuff (trademarks, Open Product License update, etc.)
  • Version 2.0 of the open source solar generator (design refinement)
  • Open Product Lab - fit the solar generator for applications such as education, farming, makers, etc.
  • Background research for key partners, both profit and non-profit, to move the new open source solar movement forward

All contributors receive exclusive updates with their limited edition perk.

 

Perks

March 12th - New Perk by Request!

For those that want to support the cause to make iPower Station the Emergency Power Response standard for disaster relief.

We send a Thank You email for making a difference. 


  

March 7th - New Perk!

We’ve made it very easy to go solar. Be ready with an emergency solar generator and never be left in the dark.

This is only a plan, and includes bill of materials with assembly instructions.
See our 'Dare to Compare' preview (here).

For a picture packed 41 page build manual, take a look at our $35.00 Perk.

Thank you - $5.00 from this perk is applied to Solar for Sandy emergency solar generators.

 

Recieve Emergency Generator Plan and listed on our Funder's Page.

Most active duty service and veterans know the drill:
Provide humanitarian mutual aid in a natural disaster.

Our House of Representatives have failed our fellow Americans - obstructing and delaying desperately needed aid, in turn, making this natural disaster into a wider disaster of man-made destruction.  It’s unacceptable.  So we’re going to route around their unnecessary damage.

This is helping our fellow citizens and neighbors in their time of need.

We set $10.00 out of each $20.00, $35.00, and $50.00 perk for building these solar generators to send to families in New Jersey.  (See specs here).  It’s how Americans are supposed to roll.  Thank you for mounting up.  Let’s get this done.

Be sure to check the updates to follow our progress.

 

 

Thank you - another $10.00 added to Solar for Sandy!

We email you a PDF plan for a 45 watt solar generator.  Step by step directions with photos using the same high quality components as our iPower Stations.  (See preview here)

Includes a list of the best multipurpose portable power packs and explains the Open Product License.

 

 

Thank you - 10 more dollars added to Solar for Sandy!

We email you a PDF plan for a 45 watt solar generator. Step by step directions with photos using the same high quality components as our iPower Stations.

Includes a list of the best multipurpose portable power packs and explains the Open Product License.

ALSO receive “25 Ways of Solar” (Preview here) which explores 25 different ways to put your portable solar generator to good use. Power when and where you need it.

 

March 1st - New Perk!

Designed to produce power for decades!

  • 45 watt solar panel - 25 year warranty.
  • Patent PWM charge controller - 10 year warranty.
  • PVC tilt frame - pinch free and corrosion proof.

Choose from hundreds of power packs (not included) with a 12 volt outlet. Combine up to three solar generators for more power production.

With just over 30 days remaining, 50 dollars from this perk is applied to
Solar for Sandy emergency solar generators.  Thank you!

 

Practical Solar Power - Ready to Go!

If you’ve ever put Ikea furniture together, then you’re ready for this 45 watt solar generator kit. It’s that easy to assemble.

The multi-purpose power pack is ready to use right out of the box. This small power pack has big features:

  • Power outlets for DC, AC, and USB
  • Jumper cables and air compressor
  • LED emergency light
  • LED power indicator

ALSO receive a PDF copy of “25 Ways of Solar.”

Thank you for joining and supporting open source solar power.

 

 

Practical Solar Power - Ready to Go!

Easy to assemble 100 watt solar generator kit.  The limited edition iPower Pack is ready to use right out of the box.  It includes a maintenance free battery rated at 75 amp-hour with 2 AC and 1 DC outlet. More power to:

  • Run a full size refrigerator or freezer during a utility outage
  • Take the home office off the grid to reduce the electric bill
  • Carry tools or gear in top compartment

ALSO receive a PDF copy of “25 Ways of Solar.”

Thank you for joining and supporting open source solar power.

 

If we reach $15,000.00 in funding, then all Contributors receive a special pre-release of “Make Your Solar Pay” PDF.

Open source, solar power, mutual aid....

You make the difference. Together, we make things better.

story:
I am a 13-year-old girl who is attending HoneyFernSchool in Marietta, Georgia. At HoneyFern our learning is project-based and individualized to each student. I have chosen to help tackle the growing obesity epidemic by showing everyone how easy it is to grow affordable, nutritious food. As you know obesity is a major concern in young adults. I will be looking how to grow nutritious food in small spaces. Not everyone has the luxury of fertile land to grow food, and I am currently exploring hydroponics since it does not require soil.

 

Since money is also a factor in poor diet habits, I am trying to use recycled materials to build a greenhouse and everyday household items to build my hydroponics system. I have been successful in gathering my materials and getting my hydroponics up and running. However, I will require a solar panel to convert the sun’s rays into the energy I need to power the system.

 

When the project is complete and I have worked out all the details, I plan on creating free blueprints for others to follow the project on my blog. I will include my letters asking for donations along with how and where I gathered my materials.  I will go in depth into my plans to build the greenhouse and the hydroponics system. Please help me reach my goals to combat obesity and help others realize that healthy food is affordable and obtainable by all.

 

Where you come in:

          Please consider donations so that I can fund the solar panel portion of my project. Your money will go directly to buying the materials needed to set up the solar panel.  Any extra funds gathered will be used to supplement the seeds and ladybugs I am using for planting and pollination.

 

How else can you help?

Please repost this on your Facebook, blogs, and Twitter accounts. Please help me spread the word.

I have been successful in gathering my materials and getting my hydroponics up and running. However, I will require a solar panel to convert the sun’s rays into the energy I need to power the system.
 
When the project is complete and I have worked out all the details, I plan on creating free blueprints for others to follow the project on my blog. I will include my letters asking for donations along with how and where I gathered my materials.  I will go in depth into my plans to build the greenhouse and the hydroponics system. Please help me reach my goals to combat obesity and help others realize that healthy food is affordable and obtainable by all.
 
Where you come in:
          Please consider donations so that I can fund the solar panel portion of my project. Your money will go directly to buying the materials needed to set up the solar panel.  Any extra funds gathered will be used to supplement the seeds and ladybugs I am using for planting and pollination.
 
How else can you help?
Please repost this on your Facebook, blogs, and Twitter accounts. Please help me spread the word.

story:
Short Summary

We are a local group of activists working towards a Clean Energy Future.

We have been working on different issues over the passed two years, including deep-sea oil drilling in NZ waters, hydraulic fracturing ("fracking") and educational work around action on Climate Change.

For this crowd funding campaign we would like to concentrate on coal mining on the West Coast of NZ.

We feel that the development of new coal mines is a threat to humanity in a time we should be urgently acting on Climate Change. Furthermore, the proposed coal mines will destroy places of unparalleled natural beauty, rare ecosystems and habitat to endangered endemic species. Many of the areas where coal mines are proposed, are on NZ conservation estate, but our Government is very friendly towards this dirty industry, so unless ordinary people stand up and say Enough!, these places will be lost.

There are a few organizations working on this campaign (through the Courts and building public opinion), but we feel that we need to strenghten a grass roots movement to compliment what bigger organizations with better funding are doing.

The attached video is produced by the Royal Forest&Bird Society who has carried out extensive biodiversity work in the area. It will give you an idea of what is at stake. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

With the raised funds, we would like to put together campaign materials to educate people about the threat of coal mining and possible alternatives.

The majority of the fundraising however will be put towards equipment for wildlife surveys and field work. We would like to put together a kit containing tents, a portable biodigester toilet, a solar cooker, tarps, GPS and mountain radio, safety gear, first aid kit, food storage and a solar charger for a laptop computer.

We will source as much of the equipment as possible privately. We do not receive contributions from any organization. We will share all equipment, data and people power with anyone involved in stopping coal mining on the West Coast and developing sustainable solutions.

Any amount of money raised will help. We are also trying to fundraise locally.

Your contribution is much appreciated. Please check out our perks...

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are interested in helping out with this campaign but can't contribute any money, you might want to consider one of the following actions:

- Please share our campaign through your social media channels and encourage your frinds to support this cause.

- Or "like" us on facebook and be kept up-to-date with what we get up to and some of the issues we work on. https://www.facebook.com/CleanEnergyFutureAction

story:
What’s that you say? 1% for the Planet does #earthdayeveryday? It’s April, earth month, and we are celebrating those environmental players that work on our big blue planet all day every day.

Earth Day is meant to inspire. Remind us to keep the planet in focus when we act. Invite people to think differently. It takes 1 action, 1 person to make change to make 1 a really big number.

This 1 book brought to us by 1 person representing many photographers (like the photo above by Ben Moon) and musicians inspired us! It reminds us why we do what we do in work and play. It lifted our heads and our hearts. And we believe it will do the same for you.

1% for the Planet is on a mission this April. Let’s show the world the power of 1. Help us with this modest goal. We want to raise $11,111 in April, to show the world that earth month matters. With a $25 donation to us, we are able to support one of the largest environmental networks in the world, and you get this really amazing book and mixtape too!

Going Out Is Going In brings together an extraordinary group of top photographers and musicians to support us!

This limited edition book, curated and edited by Jeff Johnson and James Joiner and produced by Patagonia, features work by some of today’s leading lifestyle, adventure, and outdoor photographers: Andy Mann, Becca Skinner, Ben Moon, Chris Burkard, Forest Woodward, James Q. Martin, Sam Horine, Tamara Hastie,  as well as Jeff Johnson and James Joiner.

It also will come with a free digital mixtape featuring songs generously donated by artists and internationally renowned acts: Modest Mouse, Jack Johnson, Dawes, The Head & The Heart, Bahamas, Beats Antique, The Heartless Bastards, G Love & Special Sauce, Toro y Moi, Matt Costa, Ben Sollee, Strand of Oaks, Blind Pilot, The Hold Steady, Lettuce, Delta Spirit, Nicki Bluhm & the Gramblers, Torres, PHOX, Nicole Atkins, Fruition, Robert Ellis, Annie Bethancourt, Ages & Ages, The Amazing, Deer Tick, Kate Tucker & the Sons of Sweden, CP Stelling, Daniel Ellsworth & the Great Lakes, Avers, Happiness, Ghost Punch, Quiet Life, Rozz & the Rice Cakes, Houndmouth, River Whyless, AL, Mimicking Birds, JP Harris & the Tough Choices, Neil Halstead, Trapper Schoep, Eastern Conference Champions.

Going Out is Going In and it’s mixtape will inspire you to have #earthdayeveryday too.

We are so fortunate to have friends and ambassadors like Jeff and James, and the 50+ artists who gave their time and talent to this project. Their images and music resonate, inspiring us all to give back to the planet we love.

Help us reach our $11,111 goal in April, enjoy your book and plan your next adventure.

For those of you new to us, 1% for the Planet is a global network bringing together businesses that donate 1% of sales annually to nonprofit organizations focused on the environment. Over 1,000 member companies in 41 countries give back to this big blue planet through more than 3,600 nonprofit partners. Started in 2002 by Patagonia founder and owner Yvon Chouinard and Craig Mathews, owner of Blue Ribbon Flies, 1% for the Planet helps people buy better products and protect the planet on which we work and play. To date, the network has given more than $115 million back to blue. To learn more, visit the 1% for the Planet.

story:
LANDFILL BIN STICKERS

~Help stop recyclables from going to landfill!~

Landfill Bin Stickers remind people what really happens when they place their bottles, cans and papers in the wrong bin. 

Join a community helping to take this across the city. 
Together we can make a HUGE impact!  


THE IMPACT

  • Make your community more sustainable
  • Reduce the consumption of non-recyclable goods
  • Advocate for more clearly marked bins


HOW IT WORKS

This is a TEAM BUY... 
ie. Contributions are rewarded with stickers at COST. 

We will purchase 1,000 stickers to cover the city this spring/summer. 
The project will be funded once we reach $500.


HOW TO GET THEM!

Pick up: Monday-Friday, 8am - 6pm, 215 Spadina Avenue, 4th Floor, magazine rack beside elevators.

*If you don't want to put up your stickers, please let us know and the team will put them up on your behalf.

story:
PHASE 2--The Land

Our Mission~
    To provide a sanctuary for wolves and wolfdogs. 
    To proffer an inexpensive way and place for people to live.
    To encourage sustainable, simple, healthy, organic lifestyles.
    To preserve ancient land.
    To host workshops and seminars on various topics for healthy living.
    To encourage intentional community involvement.
    To build a sustainable earthen cob village.
    To protect and preserve our planet.
    All of the above, all in one.



Our Vision~
    Blue Wolf Sanctuary and Cob Village will rest in the Appalachian Mountains of western North Carolina, providing a sanctuary for wolves and wolf dogs and creating a cob village (see below for more info on cob) on scenic mountains, ancient lands.  Families and individuals will be able to come to property to live and build a cob home.  Everyone in the intentional living community will pitch in to help and lovingly welcome the new family to our village and lifestyle.  With each cob home averaging around $10,000 to build, we can provide an option for people to live inexpensively and debt-free, with no electricity bills--our village will be entirely run off of solar, wind, and hydroelectric power.  The village will include a bed and breakfast to provide lodging for those traveling, attending seminars, workshops and gatherings, spiritual retreats, or touring the wolf sanctuary.  Organic gardens will supply the bed and breakfast and the people of the village with fresh veggies, fruit, and herbs.  Free range goats, cows, and chickens will provide fresh dairy and eggs. An artist 'cobstel' will be available to traveling artists and musicians at a low/no cost/barter.  An apothecary shed for hosting workshops and seminars on candle and soap making, lotions, herbal teas, poultices, and other types of herbal remedies.  Our vision is also our intention, and we hope it will become yours too. Join us!


 
 
 

What we need:

      Approximately 50 acres in the Appalachian mountain range of western North Carolina will provide adequate space and habitat for our wolves and wolf dogs, village, and gardens.  A waterfall or river on the land will be required for generating hydroelectric power.  A portion of the land will be dedicated to the wolf sanctuary, the other will hold the village and organic gardens. Our goal is acquire the land by spring of 2013, so we can start building and have the sanctuary built and ready before winter--and before hunting season begins next year.

     The funds raised from this campaign will go towards the land we need. If we reach our goal and raise more than is needed for the land, it will go to building costs (Solar panels, kitchen equipment, digging the well, etc) and/or care for the wolves (food, veternarians, housing, etc)  In total, our entire village and wolf sanctuary will cost approximately $300,000. This may seem like a lot, but we are confident that we can do it, especially with your help!

 


So..Why Wolves?
    Wolves/wolfdogs may possibly be some of the most misunderstood creatures; they are highly intelligent, extremely loyal, and compassionate. They mate for life, have families, and live in packs. It is a common misconception that wolves seek to harm humans.  Wolves are actually afraid of humans; their only true predator is man..
Studies have shown that 60-90% of mortalities in wolves are through human causes via trapping, poisoning, and hunting..  
  • Wolves are not the "Big Bad Wolf" as portrayed in fairy tales. They are timid around humans.
  • Extinct in many areas of the world; places where they use to run freely and live their life to no avail..
  • Wolves are so often hunted because they are viewed as a 'threat' to farmers and ranchers. However, according to data released by the USDA in 2011, wolves contributed to less than 1% of all cattle and sheep losses. Wolves do not prefer livestock, and will typically only view it as prey if there is nothing else.
  • Wolves help balance the ecosystem.  Wolves are carnivorous, feeding on herbivores (animals that feed on plant life such as moose, elk, deer, rabbit, and mice). Many of these animals tend to eat large amounts of roots, saplings, shoots, crops, and other plant material. Therefore, crops tend to thrive more lively when the wolves are around.  This is the balance of life, and wolves are a crucial part of this tenuous balance. Wolf spelled backwards is flow~
  • The average life expectancy of a wolf in the wild is 6-8 years, but in captivity they enjoy a lifespan of up to 13-18 years.
  • When wolves do well, biodiversity thrives.
  • Wolves have a complex social hierarchy. The pack usually consists of 4-8 wolves, including the Alpha male and female, though larger packs may have two pairs of Alpha male and females to provide structure and insure protection of the pack. Their rank is usually determined by their size and health.
  • Wolves rarely bark; but they do howl. At any time of day or night. To call to their pack. To communicate to other packs when a large and favorite prey has been discovered. They howl for sheer joy. They howl in warning and in loss.
  • The world has already lost 7 different species of wolves.
  • ~Extinction is forever~

  Blue Wolf plans to provide full housing and any services necessary for wolves.  The nonprofit sanctuary will rest in the Appalachian Mountains, in a habitat where the wolves will thrive happily, have plenty of room to run, and freely express themselves. Blue Wolf is dedicated to help put an end to the wolves' demise through education, rescue efforts, rehabilitation, lobbying, and whatever it takes to help humanity find a way to coexist with them.

 
About Cob~

    Cob (which means lump) is an ancient method for building and is an efficient use of natural materials. (a mixture of clay, sand, straw, and water).

  •  Building with cob is simple, inexpensive, and resourceful--most materials for building can be obtained from the homesite.
  • No building experience required, and power tools are not necessary.
  • Aesthetically appealing at a low cost--a small home can be built for $5000 (If you are resourceful.)
  • Naturally insulating and durable, with many cob homes lasting over 700 years through many natural disasters, and are even fire resistant! In fact, pizza ovens and fireplaces can be made out of cob simply by omitting the straw.
  • Fully self-sustaining earthen project
  • We will use only natural energy: solar, wind, and hydroelectric power.
  • Approximately 30% of the homes in the world are built of earth, and approximately 50% of people in developing countries live in earthen homes.
  • Easily create storage, shelving, cabinets, furniture, garden walls, countertops, pizza ovens, sink basins, bathtubs, showers, fireplaces and much more out of cob.
  • Inspires creativity--your home is your canvas!

Living Roofs-a thick blanket of turf,  plants, flowers, and herbs

  • beneficial to the environment and those who live in, under, and around it.
  • keep the home cool in the summer, warm in the winter.
  • decrease global warming effect
  • absorb 85% of rainfall
  • improves air quality-the plant material absorbs carbon dioxide and excess pollution from the atmosphere, and releases oxygen into the air.

    Our non-profit organization will include a fully sustainable bed and breakfast with 7 "cobins."  Guests will be able to visit the wolves in their sanctuary and experience their true nature firsthand. Workshops and seminars will be held for people to enjoy during their stay, with a wide range of topics including building with cob, soap and candle making, natural healing and herbalism, music instruction, martial arts, and more.  Eventually we hope to be able to travel to places in need and provide them with cob homes and shelters so they too may enjoy a fully self-sustainable lifestyle.
 
For the Artists~
    The village will also be home to an artist 'cobstel', a cobin that will be available at low to no cost/barter to traveling artists of all kinds, shapes and sizes in need of a warm bed and a home-cooked meal.. It will sleep 8 people at a time so we are able to accomodate the needs of traveling groups or bands.

 
 
OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
Don't worry if you are not able to make a contribution--Spreading the word can be just as helpful! Tell your friends and family, share on facebook, & spread the love!
 
 
Thank you for time, support, and contributions!
            With love, light, and gratitude, Gregg, Jeri, Jaime, and the Wolves of the

story:
Summary-          

Hi my name is James Gibeson. I have a background in mechanical engineering and most recently as an entrepreneur. I’m currently living in Newport Beach where I’m starting my next venture.

Right now there is and island of trash twice the size of Texas floating in the Pacific. This mass of plastic and Styrofoam is responsible for killing thousands of marine animals like sea turtles and over a million birds every year. 

Project Harmony will raise awareness for the North Pacific Garbage Patch by turning an old delivery van into a mobile museum. While parked at the boardwalk, this mobile museum will educate the public about how trash makes its journey into the ocean. The mobile museum will be decked out (literally) so that people can walk inside and view displays on the first and second levels. While visiting the museum, people will be invited to a free concert, which takes place on the beach. Admission to the concert is simply to collect as much trash as possible from our polluted beaches.

The end result is that we will reach thousands of people, educate them and clean hundreds of miles of coastline.

Long-term funding for the mobile museum will come from donations and selling trash related artwork, clothing, and accessories from the museum store.

Project Harmony is an open source project- open to everyone! There will be ample opportunities for surfing, filmmaking, playing music, and more as we travel with the mobile museum. The more we can get the word out the better!

Your contribution to get this project off the ground is very important. With your help we can build a mobile museum that will educate thousands of people and clean over 114 miles of coastline in Southern California. Your contribution of $100, $60, or even $10 will make a positive impact on our environment. I personally welcome you into this exciting project and can’t wait to get started!!


What we need-

We already have the delivery van, so now it’s just matter of transforming it into a mobile museum.

This requires a structurally sound roof, railings, lower structural support, hydrologic leveling jacks, stairs, windows, flooring, museum displays, electrical generator, battery bank, inverter, converter, electronics for showing videos, speakers, and graphics for the outside to draw people in.

We also need to setup the museum store, stock it with clothing, accessories, and art work, build a website, and buy insurance.

You’d be surprised how fast everything adds up, but we can get it done with enough boot-strapping!

Other things we need:

  • A place to do the conversion near Newport Beach- Eg. shop, garage, parking lot with power and running water.
  • Used Fryer oil- The mobile museum already runs on this eco-friendly fuel! If you work at a restaurant or know someone who does, please find out if we can collect your used fryer oil. 
  • RV parts- leveling jacks, AC unit, heater, electrical generator, plumbing tanks, sinks, refrigerator.
  • Steel- pipes, poles, I-beams, sheets, etc.
  • Aluminum- pipes, poles, I-beams, sheets, etc.
  • Wood- plywood, 2X4's, etc.
  • Bamboo poles, bamboo matting, palm materials, etc.
  • Old bench seats from a restaurant or or upholstery supplies.
  • Golf cart batteries (for the battery bank)- Trojan T-105's preferred.
  • The use of certain tools- angle grinder, plasma cutter, welder (TIG and stick).

Volunteers; especially if you have certain skills:

  • Welding/fabrication
  • Carpentry
  • Graphic design
  • Filmmaking
  • Photography
  • Clothing design
  • Website design and coding
  • Making music/playing in a band
  • Surfing
  • Sunbathing
  • All skills welcome/everyone is welcome!
     

Other ways you can help-

  • Help spread the word!
  • Share our campaign with your friends who care about the environment, animals, health, the ocean, or who enjoy the beach!
story_txt:
Summary-          


Hi my name is James Gibeson. I have a background in mechanical engineering and most recently as an entrepreneur. I’m currently living in Newport Beach where I’m starting my next venture.
Right now there is and island of trash twice the size of Texas floating in the Pacific. This mass of plastic and Styrofoam is responsible for killing thousands of marine animals like sea turtles and over a million birds every year. 
Project Harmony will raise awareness for the North Pacific Garbage Patch by turning an old delivery van into a mobile museum. While parked at the boardwalk, this mobile museum will educate the public about how trash makes its journey into the ocean. The mobile museum will be decked out (literally) so that people can walk inside and view displays on the first and second levels. While visiting the museum, people will be invited to a free concert, which takes place on the beach. Admission to the concert is simply to collect as much trash as possible from our polluted beaches.
The end result is that we will reach thousands of people, educate them and clean hundreds of miles of coastline.
Long-term funding for the mobile museum will come from donations and selling trash related artwork, clothing, and accessories from the museum store.
Project Harmony is an open source project- open to everyone! There will be ample opportunities for surfing, filmmaking, playing music, and more as we travel with the mobile museum. The more we can get the word out the better!
Your contribution to get this project off the ground is very important. With your help we can build a mobile museum that will educate thousands of people and clean over 114 miles of coastline in Southern California. Your contribution of $100, $60, or even $10 will make a positive impact on our environment. I personally welcome you into this exciting project and can’t wait to get started!!

What we need-
We already have the delivery van, so now it’s just matter of transforming it into a mobile museum.

This requires a structurally sound roof, railings, lower structural support, hydrologic leveling jacks, stairs, windows, flooring, museum displays, electrical generator, battery bank, inverter, converter, electronics for showing videos, speakers, and graphics for the outside to draw people in.
We also need to setup the museum store, stock it with clothing, accessories, and art work, build a website, and buy insurance.
You’d be surprised how fast everything adds up, but we can get it done with enough boot-strapping!
Other things we need:

A place to do the conversion near Newport Beach- Eg. shop, garage, parking lot with power and running water.
Used Fryer oil- The mobile museum already runs on this eco-friendly fuel! If you work at a restaurant or know someone who does, please find out if we can collect your used fryer oil. 
RV parts- leveling jacks, AC unit, heater, electrical generator, plumbing tanks, sinks, refrigerator.
Steel- pipes, poles, I-beams, sheets, etc.
Aluminum- pipes, poles, I-beams, sheets, etc.
Wood- plywood, 2X4's, etc.
Bamboo poles, bamboo matting, palm materials, etc.
Old bench seats from a restaurant or or upholstery supplies.
Golf cart batteries (for the battery bank)- Trojan T-105's preferred.
The use of certain tools- angle grinder, plasma cutter, welder (TIG and stick).
Volunteers; especially if you have certain skills:

Welding/fabrication
Carpentry
Graphic design
Filmmaking
Photography
Clothing design
Website design and coding
Making music/playing in a band
Surfing
Sunbathing
All skills welcome/everyone is welcome! 

Other ways you can help-


Help spread the word!
Share our campaign with your friends who care about the environment, animals, health, the ocean, or who enjoy the beach!

story:
Short Summary

I will be travelling to the Unist'ot'en pipeline blockade camp in the unceded and sovereign  Wet'suwet'en traditional territories, in what we call northern British Columbia. The Wet'suwet'en hereditary chiefs have declared their unequivocal rejection of all the pipeline projects which have been proposed and approved through federal and provincial bodies. The Wet'suwet'en have never surrendered their territories, have never signed any treaties, and are asserting their sovereignty and traditional law to protect their land, so that they can ensure the survival of their culture and way of life for future generations. 

  • I am a 29-year old non-Aboriginal graduate student of counselling psychology, currently living in Calgary, Alberta.
  • After living in BC for the last 7 years, it has become very clear to me that it is time for me to join in the resistance against colonial oppression and environmental degradation. We are all responsible for what we allow to happen to the land and to First Nations peoples in the name of 'economic development'. 
  • As requested of all volunteers seeking to spend periods at the Unist'ot'en camp, I am raising funds to help support the blockade. Funds would be spent at the discretion of the Unist'ot'en Camp leadership for essential supplies such as food, deep cycle marine batteries, camping gear, flashlights/lanterns, toilet paper, fuel, etc.

The Wet'suwet'en rightly believe that the multiple 'light natural gas' and tar-sands pipelines which have been 'approved' to be built across their territories (including Enbridge's 'Northern Gateway' tar-sands pipeline) will inevitably result in irreversible damage to their land and their traditional way of life. The Wet'suwet'en have not been consulted in any meaningful way, and they are standing up, along with other First Nations in BC and across Canada, and other Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal allies. Persons volunteering at Unist'ot'en camp are engaging in direct action to obstruct any pipeline-related activity in Wet'suwet'en territories. This means restricting access to these territories, to keep government and oil companies from where they have no free, prior and informed consent to be.

Please feel free to read the final arguments the Wet'suwet'en made against the Enbridge 'Northern Gateway' pipeline. In it, they make clear that their culture and their law IS the land; they cannot be separated, because they are interdependent. Their sound arguments were ignored by a flawed review process:

http://www.wetsuweten.com/files/FINAL_ARGUMENT.pdf

What We Need & What You Get

  • I have set a high target because I believe this to be an extremely worthy cause. The Unist'ot'en have taken a strong stand in defence of their land and culture. In so doing they have become one of the foremost obstacles in the path of these insane pipeline projects which would result in massive environmental damage. I am humbled by all they have accomplished and I want to do my part to help them build on their momentum, in my small way
  • You can be a part of this too! If you can't volunteer or travel to Unist'ot'en Camp, you can donate!
  • No matter how much money is raised, and if it doesn't reach its goal, all funds will go to the Unist'ot'en Camp. I will be attending in early May 2015 as a volunteer and will personally pass along these funds to the leadership of the camp.

Risks and Challenges

Presently, this is a 'soft blockade', meaning non-violent tactics are being practiced. Trespassers, mainly persons working for or consulting with the oil companies pushing these projects, are being evicted. They are being told that if they return their equipment will be confiscated. Presently, there appears to be no immediate threat of direct and forceful government intervention, but circumstances may change. This camp has operated for many years as a soft blockade. But if circumstances do change, the Wet'suwet'en will not stand down. They will defend their territory. They have this right under traditional law, and as human beings fighting for their very survival as a culture.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate money, here's what you can do:

  • Make some NOISE about my campaign! Post it to facebook, twitter...e-mail it to grandma! And please use Indiegogo's sharing tools as much as possible.
  • Learn more about these pipelines, their environmental impacts, and the way the governments and oil companies have treated the First Nations that stand in their way like children in need of education! Talk to others about what you have learned. Speak out, and speak up!! BE LOUD!
  • Help to organize local solidarity actions, to show support for the pipeline blockades happening across Canada, especially those in BC where so many pipelines are being pushed through. 
  • Find your own ways of helping. Find your own ways of raising consciousness, fighting racism, colonization, and environmental pillage.
  • VOTE! For the lesser of evils. Vote strategically for progressive change. Or eat your ballot and prepare to be arrested !(Mustard and Elections Canada paper go well with some crunchy lettuce in a bun...just a thought).

And that's all there is to it.

story:
HELLO!

my name is Alana Fitzgerald. I am a young artist living in NYC, still coming to terms with the fact that last fall a hurricane devastated large sections of our coastline. I was living in Rockaway Beach, NY at the time and watched from a friend's second floor window as the Beach and the Bay met one another, the flooding turned the streets to waterways and the town was literally turned upside down by the power of the enraged Atlantic Ocean. I like many others, lost my home in the disaster. It changed my life. However, there was an amazing silver lining. People came together to help one another in this intense and uneasy situation like I've never seen before. In new york city, such an event was unprecedented as far as anyone can remember. We were able to finally see first hand the impact that civilization has been making upon the earth, to understand how fragile the balance is between Man and Nature. Grateful in the aftermath to be alive and unharmed, I have made it my mission to spread awareness about how important it is to honor and protect our mother earth and her precious waters. There have been many disasters lately in the oceans which have been frightening, and I believe that prayer is a good way to align our consciousness towards positive change of the way we interact with our environment. 

 On October 18th, 2013, I plan to hold a water blessing ceremony in Rockaway Beach, NY. Essentially this is a prayer, inspired by Masaru Dr. Emoto's findings that water holds memory, intent and vibration. When we sing to the water, pray to the water, speak to the water- it is restructured, healed in a sense. It has a type of understanding that we are thankful, that we desire peace and good health. We have the power to transmit our spirit this way, put our loving hearts and good intentions out there into the ocean, and I believe that this effects the water of the entire planet in a positive way. 

New York City is a diverse place full of rich cultural and spiritual traditions. I plan to celebrate this with a non-denominational earth based ceremony. I have invited Native American leaders and elders from the Lakota and Taino people to pray with me as well as my very good friend and NYC spiritual leader Shiva Singh. 

This Water Blessing Ceremony will include an offering of flowers, wishes and food to the ocean, chants, drumming and songs and community prayers read aloud for all to hear. Afterwards we will celebrate with a feast at Veggie Island, a lovely beacon of local organic food and one of the centers of the relief effort in the aftermath of the storm. It should be a beautiful way to remember the hurricane and to offer peace and gratitude to our oceans, as well as love and healing to the community.

I am asking you if you will help me raise the money to do this. I need plane tickets for our out of town guests as well as food, transportation and housing, and materials for the offerings (we need tons of flowers!). I also would love to be able to cater this event and make it all happen in a comfortable and wonderful way. I am grateful for support of any kind. 

Thank you so much. 

LOVE

Alana Fitzgerald

http://www.alanafitzgerald.com

story:
Our Story

We are creating an 30 minute film for family audiences. What you will see in this short 4-minute film is one scene from the storyline. We shot this short demo in order to give people a taste of our project. In the story, we began by asking the question  "What would happen if an eleven-year-old urban girl was forced to live in a remote cabin in Northern Ontario with an eccentric aunt? And what would happen if that same aunt– a long time activist and a woman driven with worry for the environment–  chose to live a garbage-free lifestyle?  Years ago, I visited a friend of mine who lives in a small northern Ontario town, who had taken on that very task. She had reduced her garbage down to one, very small plastic bag a month. At the time, we were so inspired by her dedication that I, along with composer Lise Vaugeois and performer Jennifer Garrett, wrote and toured a theatre piece, then titled “Under the Moon with Aunt Birdie”. (Incidentally, the chamber orchestra version of the story will be produced this season by the Thunder Bay Symphony Orchestra).


During our performance run, we invited filmmaker Sonja Obljubek, to film archival footage. She thought it would make a great premise for a film. This percolated in the back of my mind for years until one day, I picked up my pen and wrote a film script, (not all in one day, naturally), re-titling it “Under the Pearl Moon”. Once I could think and create in a visual language, the story expanded to include neighbours, a boy with a bit of a chip on his shoulders, a woman with vision loss, and an ancient pine tree. Out of necessity, this eclectic group becomes Pearl's community. And in the end, it is Pearl who discovers a sense of wonder and awe in nature, thus teaching her aunt how to return to that place of connection with the natural world.


Children, I fear, are not always encouraged or given opportunities to develop connections with the natural world. It is one of our most basic human rights, I believe; to have access to the natural world. Only then will any of us have the passion and desire to truly become responsible stewards of our earth.


As this has been in development for years, other components and community people have become part of this project. Filmmaker Sonja Obljubek will co-direct the piece with myself- Eleanor Albanese. Lise Vaugeois will incorporate some of the music she originally composed. Eco Superior Thunder Bay has contributed to the educational component of this project. Thunder Bay Art Gallery have stepped in as a partner. And Confederation College Film Program are offering donations-in-kind.  As well as producing the film, environmental-arts lesson plans have been developed for teachers to use in classrooms. An educational package and website will be made available to teachers across the county and internationally. And the film itself will visit environmental film festivals worldwide.


It's a tall project with a tall order. Our message, in a nutshell is, “remember to be inspired in and with the natural world”. We have some core funding from arts councils and the City of Thunder Bay but we are looking for individuals and businesses to become friends of this project. With this additional funding in place, we will be able to fairly reimburse the production team and acting talent.  And we will be able to produce the high quality film we intend to offer our audiences.  Late this Fall, we will shoot the film. Over the winter and spring, we will edit it, integrate original music, and finally send it out to delight and inspire family audiences everywhere. Will you invest in this vision? Ultimately, it is our way of giving back to this extraordinary planet, and encouraging stewardship for all.


Please help us get the word out so that we are able to reach our goal!
