story:
Who Are We & What is Sacred Earth Camp?

Sacred Earth Environmental Justice Camp is a two-week, outdoor intensive on an organic farm and conservation centre. Workshops with local, grassroots organizers, First Nations, activists, farmers, media artists, land defenders, and workers will ground indigenous, settler and immigrant youth and young adults in the environmental justice issues of our bio-region, equip them with practical skills for effective change, and nurture spiritual practices for the long haul. All with generous helpings of community, music, laughter, and fun.

Salal & Cedar is a Watershed Discipleship community. We are committed to the way that the Christian story both calls and equips us for the work of environmental justice. When we asked young people in the lower Fraser watershed, Coast Salish Territory, how they feel about the environment they told us:
  • creation is where we are spiritually connected
  • we are deeply concerned about pollution, species extinction & climate change
  • we want to know how to make a real difference

We listened and responded with Sacred Earth Camp. We have the team and the location but we need your financial gift to make this program the best it can be.

Meet Our Talented and Passionate Team

Laurel Dykstra Priest in Charge, Salal & Cedar. I began my activism as a high-school student. I have experience in street theatre, popular education, program design, mentorship, and community organizing. I am an anti-racism trainer, Truth and Reconciliation Commission participant, and published author. I have lived most of my life on Coast Salish territory and am an enthusiastic amateur naturalist and birder.

Brander McDonald Indigenous Relations Coordinator, Mennonite Church BC and Indigenous Justice Ministries Coordinator, Diocese of New Westminster. I am a member of the Cree Nation, Peguis Band. I have worked in cultural education in secondary schools, in First Nations communities, in correctional centres, with Residential School survivors, as a cross-cultural communications consultant, a therapist, musician, artist, hockey coach and youth worker.

Caitlin Reilley Beck Children and Youth Ministries Coordinator, Anglican Diocese of New Westminster. I have eight years experience in children’s and youth ministry. I am a board member for CampOUT, for queer, trans and allied youth and have been to the UN Commission on the Status of Women with the International Anglican Women’s Network. I believe every voice is important in the song of God’s creation; I empower youth leaders in their communities and help older people to listen.


Matt Humphrey Assistant Director, Brooksdale Environmental Centre, A Rocha. I have background in wilderness guiding and I teach environmental theology. My passion is for integrating the life of faith into all we do. I am excited about partnership with Salal & Cedar, watershed discipleship, fruit trees, chickens, and the way we grow, cook, and share food together.

Why Should You Give?

A gift to Sacred Earth Camp is an investment in the future. You will make a lasting impact on the lives of the young people committed to making a real difference for climate justice.

Respected backers have confidence in Sacred Earth Camp:                                          The Anglican Diocese of New Westminster is covering the director's salary and program development costs.                                                                                                       St. Mary's Kerrisdale parish will pay transportation costs for one youth from a northern community or reserve.                                                                                                    A Rocha's Brooksdale Farm is the host site and will subsidize conservation and garden programming.                                                                                                                   The Anglican Ministry Investment Fund is covering fundraising expenses and room and board.                                                                                                                                               Recording artist and Foursquare minister Cheryl Bear allowed us to use her music in our promotional video.

Faith leaders for climate justice endorse our project:

At this time  of ecological and relational crisis we need the kind of leaders that Salal & Cedar will help to nurture, leaders that are prophetic, bold, capable, integrating theory and practice, faith and action.                                                                   Jennifer Henry, Executive Director KAIROS Canada

Salal & Cedar is the newest expression of a burgeoning North American Watershed Discipleship movement.  Animated by veteran biblical scholar and activist Rev. Laurel Dykstra, Sacred Earth Camp is an ideal venue for youth leadership empowerment amidst the hard realities of our ecological crisis.                            Ched Myers, Bartameaus Cooperative Ministries

The intersection of justice and hope for young Indigenous People is, to a great extent, found in the intersection of Climate Justice and Indigenous Rights.          Mark MacDonald, Indigenous Anglican Bishop

What We Need From You

Our campaign goal is $10,000. Your gift will help provide:

$3500 salary and benefits for a qualified youth worker
$2000 transportation for youth from rural and remote communities
$1500 two fully subsidized spots for indigenous youth
$1200 compensation for activists and workshop facilitators
$1000 bus and driver transportation to field sites
$800 canoe trip with Takaya Tours

The risks of giving are few. Sacred Earth Camp will run this summer. We have bare-bones funding to run the program as a pilot project for eight paying campers whose fees will cover basic program expenses. This is a "flexible funding" project so whatever amount we raise will go to increase the quality and accessibility of the camp. Any amount over our target will go towards Sacred Earth Camp 2017. Please give generously.

Everyone who gives to this project will receive a beautiful gift of original photo cards from our Forty Birds of Lent project.

Canadian contributors giving $20 or more will receive an official charitable donation receipt for tax purposes through the Anglican Diocese of New Westminster.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially we still need your help. Please:

  • Pray for the young people and project team who are committing themselves to work for environmental justice.
  • Encourage youth to come to camp: salalandcedar@vancouver.anglican.ca
  • Share this campaign with contacts and friends through e-mail, word of mouth and social media. You could even ask for a holiday gift in your honour.
story_txt:
Who Are We & What is Sacred Earth Camp?
 Sacred Earth Environmental Justice Camp is a two-week, outdoor intensive on an organic farm and conservation centre. Workshops with local, grassroots organizers, First Nations, activists, farmers, media artists, land defenders, and workers will ground indigenous, settler and immigrant youth 
and young adults in the environmental justice issues of our bio-region, equip them with practical skills for effective change, and nurture spiritual practices for the long haul. All with generous helpings of community, music, laughter, and fun.Salal & Cedar is a Watershed Discipleship community. We are committed to the way that the Christian story both calls and equips us for the work of environmental justice. When we asked young people in the lower Fraser watershed, Coast Salish Territory, how they feel about the environment they told us: 
creation is where we are spiritually connected
we are deeply concerned about pollution, species extinction & climate change

we want to know how to make a real difference


We listened and responded with Sacred Earth Camp. We have the team and the location but we need your financial gift to make this program the best it can be.


Meet Our Talented and Passionate Team



Laurel Dykstra Priest in Charge, Salal & Cedar. I began my activism as
a high-school student. I have
experience in street theatre, popular education, program design, mentorship, and
community organizing. I am an anti-racism trainer, Truth and Reconciliation Commission participant, and published author. I have lived most of my life on Coast Salish
territory and am an enthusiastic amateur naturalist and birder.



Brander McDonald Indigenous Relations Coordinator, Mennonite 
Church BC and Indigenous Justice Ministries Coordinator, Diocese of New Westminster. I am a member of the Cree Nation, Peguis 
Band. I have worked in cultural 
education in secondary schools, in First Nations communities, in 
correctional centres, with Residential School survivors, as a cross-cultural communications consultant, a therapist, 
musician, artist, hockey coach and youth worker. 




Caitlin Reilley Beck Children and Youth Ministries Coordinator,
Anglican Diocese of New Westminster. I have eight years experience in children’s
and youth ministry. I am a board member for CampOUT, for queer, trans and
allied youth and have been to the UN Commission on the Status of Women
with the International Anglican Women’s Network. I believe every voice is
important in the song of God’s creation; I empower youth leaders in their communities and help older people to listen. 

Matt Humphrey Assistant Director, Brooksdale Environmental Centre, A Rocha. I have background in wilderness guiding and I teach environmental theology. My passion is for integrating the life of faith 
into all we do. I am excited about partnership with Salal & Cedar, watershed discipleship, fruit trees, 
chickens, and the way we grow, cook, and share food together. 


Why Should You Give?

A gift to Sacred Earth Camp is an investment in the future. You will make a lasting impact on the lives of the young people committed to making a real difference for climate justice. 
Respected backers have confidence in Sacred Earth 
Camp:                                          The Anglican 
Diocese of New Westminster is covering the director's salary and program
 development 
costs.                                                                                                       St. Mary's Kerrisdale parish will pay transportation costs for one 
youth from a northern community or 
reserve.                                                                                                    A Rocha's Brooksdale Farm is the host site and will subsidize conservation and garden 
programming.                                                                                                                   The Anglican Ministry Investment Fund is covering 
fundraising expenses and room and board.                                                                                                                                               Recording artist and Foursquare minister Cheryl Bear allowed us to use her music in our promotional video. 
Faith leaders for climate justice endorse our project:


At this time  of ecological and relational crisis we need the kind of leaders that
Salal & Cedar will help to nurture, leaders that are prophetic, bold,
capable, integrating theory and practice, faith and action.                                                                   Jennifer Henry, Executive
Director KAIROS Canada

Salal & Cedar is the newest expression of a burgeoning North American Watershed
Discipleship movement.  Animated by veteran biblical scholar and activist Rev. Laurel Dykstra, Sacred Earth Camp is an ideal venue for youth leadership empowerment amidst the
hard realities of our ecological crisis.                            Ched Myers, Bartameaus Cooperative Ministries

The intersection of justice and hope for young
Indigenous People is, to a great extent, found in the intersection of Climate
Justice and Indigenous Rights.          Mark MacDonald,
Indigenous Anglican Bishop

  What We Need From You
 Our campaign goal is $10,000. Your gift will help provide:$3500 salary and benefits for a qualified youth worker $2000 transportation for youth from rural and remote communities$1500 two fully subsidized spots for indigenous youth$1200 compensation for activists and workshop facilitators$1000 bus and driver transportation to field sites$800 canoe trip with Takaya Tours

The risks of giving are few. Sacred Earth Camp will run this summer. We have bare-bones funding to run the program as a pilot project for eight paying campers whose fees will cover basic program expenses. This is a "flexible funding" project so whatever amount we raise will go to increase the quality and accessibility of the camp. Any amount over our target will go towards Sacred Earth Camp 2017. Please give generously.




Everyone who gives to this project will receive a beautiful gift of original photo cards from our Forty Birds of Lent project. 
Canadian contributors giving $20 or more will receive an official charitable donation receipt for tax purposes through the Anglican Diocese of New Westminster. 
  Other Ways You Can Help If you can't contribute financially we still need your help. Please:  Pray for the young people and project team who are committing themselves to work for environmental justice.
Encourage youth to come to camp: salalandcedar@vancouver.anglican.ca
 Share this campaign with contacts and friends through e-mail, word of mouth and social media. You could even ask for a holiday gift in your honour.

story:
Vanamoolika – Zentrum für die Erhaltung und den biologischen Anbau von Medizinalpflanzen

Vanamoolika - centre for conservation and organic cultivation of medicinal plants


Wir alle haben ein Ziel: Ein gesundes Leben!

Dafür benötigen wir eine intakte Umwelt und einen nachhaltigen Lebensstil, der die  Natur und ihre Lebewesen nicht beeinträchtigt.

Viele Bauern weltweit praktizieren biologische, nachhaltige Landwirtschaft und erhalten die Artenvielfalt - und sie tun das ganz selbstverständlich. Und eine wachsende Zahl von Verbraucher wissen dies zu schätzen, in dem sie ökologische Produkte kaufen, zu ihrem eigenem Wohle, dem der Natur und dem der Bauern. Dennoch ist die kleinbäuerliche Landwirtschaft weltweit bedroht durch die Agrar-Industrie. Sie versucht Kleinbauern, insbesondere in Entwicklungsländern aus den Märkten zu drängen.

We all want one thing: A Healthy Life!

To have that, we are totally dependent on nature. We have to live a sustainable lifestyle, a life that does not harm nature or any living being.

Many small farmers around the world practice organic farming, sustainable agriculture and biodiversity conservation as a matter of course. A growing number of consumers support these practices by buying their products for the benefit of nature, the producer, and for themselves! Yet, organic local farming is under threat by agro-industries intent on dominating the market and pushing out small farmers in developing countries.

Kerala im Südwesten Indiens ist Teil der West-Ghats, einer der acht weltweit wichtigsten UNESCO-Hotspots für Biodiversität. Dennoch können wir hier einen dramatischen Verlust an pflanzlicher und tierischer Artenvielfalt beobachten – verursacht durch unkontrollierte Wildsammlungen, Pestizidmissbrauch und Agrarindustrie mit großflächigen Monokulturen – eine fatale Entwicklung nicht nur für die Natur, sondern auch für die Lebensgrundlage zahlreicher Kleinbauern.

Aber eine kleine Organisation hier in Kerala hat eine große Vision – eine Vision einer üppigen Natur für gesunde Lenensweise. Diese Organisation trägt den klangvollen Namen ‚Vanamoolika’, was soviel bedeutet wie ‚Heilpflanzen’. Vanamoolika hat sich bereits 1991 auf den Erhalt und den biologischen Anbau von Medizinalpflanzen spezialisiert.

Kerala in Southwest India is part of the West-Ghat, one of the eight most important UNESCO biodiversity hotspots in the world. Unsustainable wild harvesting and the use of pesticides in large-scale mono-crop plantations are causing a massive loss of plant and animal biodiversity - a dreadful development not only for nature but also a threat for small farmers’ livelihoods.

But, for one small organisation, here in Kerela there is a bigger vision– a vision for a healthy life for humans and an abundant future for nature. This organisation is Vanamoolika (which means medicinal plants)! Vanamoolika since 1991 has specialised in the conservation and organic cultivation of medical plants.


In vielen Entwicklungsländern, insbesondere in ländlichen Regionen, ist ein Großteil der Menschen für ihre medizinische Grundversorgung im Wesentlichen von traditioneller Medizin abhängig. Dabei stehen in vielen Familien und Gemeinschaften meist Frauen in der Verantwortung für Vorsorge und Heilung. Sie beziehen ihre Rohstoffe für traditionelle Medizin direkt aus der Natur und spielen daher eine zentrale Rolle als Hüterinnen traditionellen Wissens – und das ist es wofür Vanamoolika steht.

In many developing countries a large part of the population, especially in rural areas, depend mainly on traditional medicine for their primary health care. Women are mostly responsible in keeping families and their communities healthy by providing preventive and curative care. Traditional medicinal plants play a central role in the resources that women draw upon.That is why women play a crucial role as keepers of traditional knowledge and that is what Vanamoolika also stands for.


Mitten im Herzen der wilden, grünen West-Ghats hat Vanamoolika über die Jahre, Schritt für Schritt, ein Zentrum für die Erhaltung von Medizinalpflanzen aufgebaut, 4 Acres Fläche, auf denen wissbegierige Frauen und Männer alles über die Erhaltung, den Anbau und die Wirkung von Medizinalpflanzen lernen können. Derzeit beherbergen die Wälder und Gärten Vanamoolikas die unglaubliche Zahl von über 700 Medizinalpflanzen – das Ergebnis von 23 Jahren harter Arbeit und ein unschätzbarer Beitrag für die Artenvielfalt Kerala. Was für ein Erfolg! Leider hat Vanamoolika für diesen Beitrag bisher keinerlei finanzielle Unterstützung oder Wertschätzung seitens offizieller Stellen erhalten.

Situated in the very middle of the wild green Western Ghats, Vanamoolika has been building over the years, step by step, an approximately 4 acre centre for the conservation of medicinal plans. Here they have created a training centre for people who are interested in learning about organic farming and the conservation and cultivation of medicinal plants. Currently, the centre hosts an unmatched number of more than 700 medicinal plants. For the last twenty-three years they have been trying hard to save the biodiversity in Kerala - and so far they have accomplished substantial successes! But Vanamoolika so far never received appreciation or financial support from donors or governmental agencies.

Daher wurde es notwendig aus Biodiversität Einkommen zu generieren. Um ihre Vision umzusetzen, wurde eine Manufaktur erbaut, in der die Heilpflanzen zu Ayurvedischen Arzneimitteln, pflanzlichen Heilmitteln und Kosmetik verarbeitet werden – biologisch und nach HACCP Standards. Diese Manufaktur wird von 375 einheimischen Frauen betrieben – Vanamoolika, als gemeinnützige Organisation – stellt die notwendigen Verarbeitungsanlagen zur Verfügung.

Erst kürzlich konnten Handelspartnerschaften mit deutschen Kleinunternehmen geschlossen werden, bei denen Kaffee und Gewürze der Bauernorganisation ‚Organic Wayanad’ für den Export aufbereitet werden.

Organic Wayanad ist ein Kollektiv von 350 lokalen Biobauern, die an Vanamoolika Gewürze wie z.B. Kardamom, Pfeffer, Ingwer, Kurkuma, aber auch andere Nichtholz-Waldprodukte wie Kaffee, Kakao, Cashew oder Kokosnüsse liefern. Die Verarbeitung und Verpackung dieser Produkte stellt mittlerweile einen wichtigen wirtschaftlichen Baustein für Vanamoolika dar.

The need grew to turn biodiversity into income. To complete their vision, they have built a manufacturing plant to process these plants into organic Ayurvedic medicine, herbal medicine and cosmetics - all by organic, and HACCP international standards. This factory belongs to 375 local women and Vanamoolika as Non-Profit-Organisation provides them the facilities to run this enterprise.

Recently they have successfully started establishing partnerships with small companies from Europe for processing coffee and organic spices from their partners Organic Wayanad. Organic Wayanad is a collective of some 350 local organic farmers that provide Vanamoolika with a number of spices such as cardamom, pepper, ginger, turmeric as well as non-wood-forest crops such as coffee, cocoa, cashew or coconut. The processing and packing of these products meanwhile makes a substantial part of Vanamoolika's income.

Warum ist die Arbeit von Vanamoolika so wichtig?

In Kerala wächst die Zahl der Industriebetriebe, die Medizinalpflanzen ernten. Die meisten dieser Unternehmen scheren sich nicht um Nachhaltigkeit oder die lokalen Gemeinschaften. Wildsammlungen, die billiger sind als der Anbau, sind außer Kontrolle geraten. Die natürliche Artenvielfalt ist gestört, was nicht nur zu einem rasanten Artenschwund führt, sondern auch Qualität und Wirksamkeit der Heilmittel drastisch verringert.

„Wenn wir der Wildsammlung nichts entgegen setzen, werden alle Medizinalpflanzen über kurz oder lang verschwinden. Denn wenn kein einziges Samenkorn mehr den Boden erreichen kann, wie soll dann im nächsten Jahr eine neue Pflanze wachsen?“, fürchtet P.J. Chackochan, Präsident von Vanamoolika.

Why is the work of Vanamoolika so important? 

In Kerala the number of industries harvesting medicinal plants is growing. Most of these businesses disregard all aspects of sustainability and community. Wild harvesting of medicinal plants from the forests, which is cheaper than their cultivation, is out of control. The result hurts natural biodiversity and is leading to an alarming rapid decrease not only of species and yield but also in quality of products.

‘If we don't stop the wild harvesting, all the medicinal plants are going to vanish. Because, if there is not even a single seed left falling into the soil, how can there be a new plant growing next year’? - President of Vanmoolika.


Vanamoolikas Menschen stehen vor großen Herausfoderungen. Der nachhaltige und biologische Anbau bei Vanamoolikas ist arbeitsintensiv, so dass die Produkte teurer sind als die der Wettbewerber. Leider erfährt biologischer Landbau in Kerala wenig Wertschätzung und die lokale Unterstützung ist gering, hauptsächlich aufgrund fehlenden Bewusstseins. Die gute Botschaft ist, dass Vanamoolika langsam wächst, dafür aber Hilfe braucht, um ein nachhaltiges Wachstum zu sichern, Hilfe, die sie unterstützen, dass Investitionen, Wissen, Tradition und all die Energie und Mühen und die Wurzeln, die das Projekt geschlagen hat, nicht zugrunde gehen.

Vanamoolika benötigt deine Unterstützung um seine wirtschaftliche Basis zu stärken! Deine Spende wird benötigt, um Kreditraten und bessere Löhne zu bezahlen, Rohware anzukaufen und damit auch Bauern und Indigene, die die Erzeuger der Rohwaren sind, eine sichere Existenz zu bieten.

Darüber hinaus möchten sie auch ihr Ziel realisieren, ein kleines medizinisches Zentrum zu betreiben, in dem die Gemeindemitglieder behandelt werden können.

There are many challenges that Vanamoolika's people face. The sustainable and organic production of Vanamoolika products is labour intensive and that makes our products more expensive than those of their competitors. Unfortunately, organic farming is still undervalued in Kerala and local support is very low, mostly due to lack of awareness among the public. The good news is that Vanamoolika is growing and needs help now to make sure that their growth is sustainable. They need help to assure that the investment, knowledge, tradition, work and sweat, the roots, which are already growing, will not die away.

Vanamoolika needs to raise money now to strengthen its financial basis! Your support will be used to pay back loans, to purchase raw materials, financially back the farmers and indigenous people in the region that are their producers, and pay a better wage to their workers.

They are also going to use this help toward our vision of building a small medical centre here in Vanamoolika that will benefit the local community.

Investiere in die Erhaltung von Artenvielfalt und in uns – die Menschen von Vanamoolika

Wir – Vanamoolika und seine Unterstützer – haben ein Minimalziel von 10.000 Euro gesteckt. Das klingt wenig angesichts der großen Vision und Herausforderungen – aber diese Geld kann viel bewegen. Hilf uns, dieses Ziel zu erreichen und vielleicht zu übertreffen!

Gib Vanamoolika eine Chance zu wachsen – es ist nicht nur für sie, sondern für dich und mich und für die Zukunft, die wir selbst gestalten!

Invest in the conservation of biodiversity and in us – the Vanamoolika people!

We – Vanamoolika and our supporters - have set a minimum target for 10.000 USD. This might seem like a little for such a big vision but we can make it go a long way! Help us meet our target and beat it!

Let's give Vanamoolika a chance to grow. It's not just for them, it’s for you and me and the future we choose to make!



VIELEN DANK - THANK YOU!!!!

Diese Kampagne wird aktiv unterstützt von

This campaign is actively supported by

 www.weitumdiewelt.de

www.quijote-kaffee.de

www.elephantbeans.de


Special thanks to

Gwen & Patrick for their lovely video and photo takes!

Leron Katsir for revising the text.

growing and needs help now to make sure that their growth is sustainable. They
need help to assure that the investment, knowledge, tradition, work and sweat,
the roots, which are already growing, will not die away.
Vanamoolika needs to raise money now to strengthen its financial basis! Your support will be used to pay back loans, to purchase raw materials,
financially back the farmers and indigenous people in the region that are their
producers, and pay a better wage to their workers.
They are also going to
use this help toward our vision of building a small medical centre here in
Vanamoolika that will benefit the local community.




Investiere in die Erhaltung von Artenvielfalt und in uns – die Menschen
von Vanamoolika
Wir – Vanamoolika und seine
Unterstützer – haben ein Minimalziel von 10.000 Euro gesteckt. Das klingt wenig
angesichts der großen Vision und Herausforderungen – aber diese Geld kann viel
bewegen. Hilf uns, dieses Ziel zu erreichen und vielleicht zu übertreffen!
Gib Vanamoolika eine Chance
zu wachsen – es ist nicht nur für sie, sondern für dich und mich und für die
Zukunft, die wir selbst gestalten!
Invest in the conservation of biodiversity and in us – the Vanamoolika
people!
We – Vanamoolika and
our supporters - have set a minimum target for 10.000 USD. This might seem like
a little for such a big vision but we can make it go a long way! Help us
meet our target and beat it! 
Let's give Vanamoolika
a chance to grow. It's not just for them, it’s for you and me and the future we
choose to make!

VIELEN DANK - THANK YOU!!!!Diese Kampagne wird aktiv unterstützt vonThis campaign is actively supported by www.weitumdiewelt.dewww.quijote-kaffee.dewww.elephantbeans.deSpecial thanks toGwen & Patrick for their lovely video and photo takes!Leron Katsir for revising the text.

story:
About the Lake Winnipeg Water Walk

In 2013, Lake Winnipeg – the 10th largest fresh water lake in the world, was nominated “Most Threatened Lake” by Global Nature Fund. It was suggested that in 10 years this lake could die if action is not taken to help her heal.

From July 12 – August 8, 2014, community members from all walks of life will come together to take part in the “Lake Winnipeg Water Walk” to help her begin that healing process. Through ceremony, prayer and song, Lake Winnipeg Water Walkers will petition the spirit for healing and bring more awareness to this issue.

Covering 1032 kilometres in 28 days, this volunteer driven effort is one of many such walks taking place across the globe to protect our sacred and living waters. Joining this growing global movement, the Lake Winnipeg Water Walk reminds us that what we do to the water, we do to ourselves.

Through community leadership and commitment, we can work collectively to ensure that our life giving water continues to flow and sustain future generations. We are all responsible for the health of our waters – the time is now.

This volunteer effort is not without costs. Fuel, lodging and food expenses to support our Lake Winnipeg Water Walkers top the list. Through your support, we will complete this walk to awaken to our relationship with, and responsibility to the water, our sacred life source.

 

About me

Booshoo!
Welcome to the Lake Winnipeg Water Walk 2014 (LWWW2014). I am the dreamer, organizer, and lead walker of LWWW2014. You might be wondering what that first word means, Booshoo. Booshoo is an Ojibway/Anishinabe word used to greet people. You would use it much the same way that you would use hello. So Booshoo!I wanted to share a little bit of information about myself so that you, as supporters of the LWWW2014, can understand and gain insight into why I have organized this walk.I am an Anishnabe woman from Southern Manitoba. My Anishnabe name is Animkiiquay (Thunder Woman), and I am a member of the Makwa clan as well as a 4th Degree Midewiwin of the 3 Fires Midewiwin Lodge. It is this strong connection to the Midewiwin teachings as well being a proud wife, mother, sister, aunt, and grandmother that drove me to do something about the poor state of Lake Winnipeg.

The 3 Fires Midewiwin Lodge is committed to teaching the Anishinabe people about our story and history through traditional teachings, ceremonies, and songs. These teachings help us live a life based on the 7 sacred laws – truth, honesty, respect, love, wisdom, humility and courage. Over the years, the 3 Fires Grand Chief, Bawdwaywidun (Edward Benton Banaise), has shared his vast knowledge regarding the Midewiwin. This has included a water bundle, teachings about the water, that has been passed on through generations of women in his family. He shared these teachings and songs with the women of the 3 Fires Lodge, preparing us for the time when he would transfer the water bundle to Anishinabequay (women). In order to ensure that this water bundle is never lost or forgotten, the 3 Fires Lodge established a society of women to entrust this water bundle to. This society consists of generational lines- grandmothers, mothers and daughters who have promised to ensure that everyone understand the importance of water and to stand up and protect the waters and life of Creation.

I am a proud to say that I am a member of this society and that I am committed to defending the waters of this land, which is the life blood of our Mother, the Earth.

 

Animkiiquay / Katherine Morrisseau-Sinclair

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We need your help:

1. We need a motorhome!

Over half of the walk is through hundreds of kms without any options for accommodation. We need to rent or borrow a motorhome so the walkers have a place to stay! This is one of our biggest costs!

 

2. We need walkers, support crew, and community hosts

Walkers: We are looking for people who are willing to
walk with the water, for 1 day, for 2 days, for the whole walk, any time
commitment at all. Extra need for walkers from July 12 – 26.

Support Crew: We need drivers, cooks, safety and
logistical support to care for our walkers by traveling to assist with food
preparation, camp set ups, laundry etc.

Community Hosts: We need contacts in each community
to support our walkers through meals, community feasts, home stays.


Check out the route information on our website for dates and location of
the walk.

3. We need donations!

Our largest expense (aside from the motorhome) is fuel!
Sponsorship information can be found on our website and we accept cash or cheques made out “Lake Winnipeg Water Walk”. Go to www.lakewinnipegwaterwalk.ca or contact Michelle at 204-223-0510 for more information.

 

Share this campaign on Facebook and email

  • Check out our website for updates and more information!
  • Join our Facebook group
  • Walk with us: This is a public event and we welcome anyone to walk with us. Check out the itinerary to see where we'll be and when.
  • Host the walkers: We need people in each community to host meals, offer a place to rest and facilitate community events. Contact us at info@lakewinnipegwaterwalk.ca if you wish to get involved!

story:
Hi Everybody,

My name is Kevyn McGraw.  I am a Canadian living in Vientiane, Lao.  Today I came accross an article documenting the amazing story Vientiane Rescue, a team of locals and expats in Vientiane volonteering their time and effort to save countless lives in this beautiful, but poor, country.

I want to help raise money to help this group purchase the Equipment needed to improve their skills and ability to help others.

Your donations will go towards purchasing new bandages, neck braces, and hopefully a hydraulic car lift to help raise cars in case of accidents.

For more information, please read the following article:

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2014-11-22/volunteers-save-lives-on-streets-of-vientiane/5910698

Thank you all for help and warm hearts.

story:
Thank you so much to everyone who has contributed to the Harbor Ring!  We have brought in almost $5000 in online and offline donations from over 60 generous supporters.  Time is running out--please contribute to the cause and help us go that extra mile by sharing our campaign with your friends!  If you would like to make a 100% tax-deductible donation after the time has elapsed, you can mail a check (with "Harbor Ring" written in the memo line) to:

Transportation Alternatives

127 W 26th St #1002

New York, NY 10001

Thanks again for your generous support!

 

Our Story

Support the Harbor Ring: an ambitious project serving bicyclists and pedestrians in the greater New York metropolitan area. 

Encircling the New York Bay, the Harbor Ring will facilitate 50 miles of waterfront recreational opportunity, bicycle transportation routes, and increased local tourism, integrating more than 28 miles of existing shared use paths and bikeways.  Connecting New York City’s Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Staten Island with the New Jersey cities of Bayonne, Jersey City, and Hoboken, the Harbor Ring will also garner support for its last missing link: bicycle and pedestrian access over the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. 

Our team needs YOUR help to produce a fold-out print map illustrating the Harbor Ring.  While our website harborring.org features the on-street route for everyone’s immediate use, the print map will showcase much, much more!  From transit connections, water sources, and restrooms to bike shops, cultural attractions, and restaurants, the official Harbor Ring map will allow visitors to make the most of their trip around the New York Bay and experience the charm of the local sights and tastes. 

Once produced and printed, we can distribute complimentary maps to bike shops, local businesses, tourist destinations, and at events, so that visitors and locals alike can experience their city in a whole new way—for free.  The more people who use and enjoy the route, the more support can grow for a bicycle and pedestrian path over the Verrazano.

The Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, which connects Brooklyn to Staten Island, is restricted to those traveling on foot or by bicycle and is the “missing link” to a complete Harbor Ring.  Built in 1964, the Verrazano Bridge was initially designed with a pedestrian and bicycle path. While the path was never constructed, the bridge was ultimately engineered to accommodate one. In honor of the Verrazano’s upcoming 50th anniversary in 2014, we’re advocating for the completion of the bridge, which will also allow for the completion the Harbor Ring.

The Harbor Ring is an advocacy project of Transportation Alternatives, New York City’s leading transportation advocacy organization.  All donations will be channeled through Transportation Alternatives, a 501(c)(3) tax exempt non profit, and will be tax-deductible to the fullest extent of the law. 

The Impact

When finished, the Harbor Ring will not only offer unprecedented recreational opportunities, it will also continue to establish the region as one of the nation’s most bike-friendly, an honor now deeply coveted by cities around the world, and make it safer and easier than ever to get around the neighborhood and to work by bicycle.  

A recent survey showed that 84% of over 700 respondents believed that the presence of a bicycle/pedestrian path over the Verrazano Bridge would “strongly encourage” them to use a bicycle as transportation between Brooklyn and Staten Island, potentially easing congestion and facilitating access to a community with one of the longest commute times in the nation.

The Harbor Ring will also spur tourism in underserved neighborhoods around the region and will make the metropolitan area an even more attractive destination.  The Harbor Ring provides stunning views of the Manhattan, Brooklyn, and Jersey City Skyline, Statue of Liberty, the Verrazano Bridge, and Ellis Island, while reconnecting residents and visitors to New York and New Jersey’s spectacular waterfront and offering access to enjoy some of the region’s most historic landmarks, 48 parks, and regional destinations.

The route also includes numerous vibrant business districts, including DUMBO, the Columbia Street Waterfront, Bay Street, Ocean Avenue, and downtown Jersey City, downtown Hoboken, and Battery Park City. The route is also rich with rail, bus, and ferry transit connections. So whether you ride the whole route, or smaller sections, there is always a way back home.

What will your contribution do?

Your contributions will go directly towards the production and printing of the map.  Each donation of $10 or more will receive an official Harbor Ring map—so please make a contribution and claim your perk today!

If we exceed our fundraising goal, any additional funds will go towards our next steps:

  1. Designing and producing official Harbor Ring street signs to officially mark the route
  2. A supported bicycle ride in 2013 for participants to bike the entire ring, with a shuttle bus to take them and their bicycles across the Verrazano Bridge at the end.
  3. Website expansion and maintenance, promotional materials, mailing and postage

Other Ways You Can Help

  1. Learn about the Harbor Ring on HarborRing.org—and email us with your ideas, suggestions, feedback at info@HarborRing.org
  2. If you live or work in the NYC/NJ area or are planning on visiting—ride the Harbor Ring!  See the route here.
  3. If you live in the NYC/NJ area, write to your local elected official and tell them that you support a bicycle/pedestrian path over the Verrazano Bridge
  4. Visit and 'Like' us on Facebook
  5. Send us a tweet at @TheHarborRing
  6. Share this campaign and spread the word!

Your contributions will go directly towards the production and printing of the map.  Each donation of $10 or more will receive an official Harbor Ring map—so please make a contribution and claim your perk today!
If we exceed our fundraising goal, any additional funds will go towards our next steps:

Designing and producing official Harbor Ring street signs to officially mark the route
A supported bicycle ride in 2013 for participants to bike the entire ring, with a shuttle bus to take them and their bicycles across the Verrazano Bridge at the end.
Website expansion and maintenance, promotional materials, mailing and postage
Other Ways You Can Help

Learn about the Harbor Ring on HarborRing.org—and email us with your ideas, suggestions, feedback at info@HarborRing.org

If you live or work in the NYC/NJ area or are planning on visiting—ride the Harbor Ring!  See the route here.
If you live in the NYC/NJ area, write to your local elected official and tell them that you support a bicycle/pedestrian path over the Verrazano Bridge
Visit and 'Like' us on Facebook

Send us a tweet at @TheHarborRing

Share this campaign and spread the word!

story:
Who are we?

We are Eddie and Kim McIntosh and our 2 year old daughter Eloise. We own, manage and run Mellowcroft Natural Holistic Retreat.

Mellowcroft is an off–grid, low impact social enterprise in Mid Wales on an ancient 12 acre smallholding.

Alongside horticulture we offer calming retreats for those seeking to escape the hectic pace of modern life and reconnect with the environment. We have community allotment space for individuals and local social groups.

Every year we offer free respite retreats for around 40 teenagers from a local charity known as Powys Young Carers, as their name suggests they are all full time carers for their own parents and siblings, they rely upon their time with us to recharge their batteries and get the opportunity to just be kids for a while.

We manage the land to encourage wildlife habitat and biodiversity with a commitment to identifying, protecting and promoting native species of flora and fauna. We work with the advice/support of the Woodland Trust and Radnorshire Wildlife Association and have regular visits to record the species on site and help it flourish.

Our management of the land has protected several ancient species of insect, one of which appears in the ‘Red Book’.

We offer free space to ‘Local Roots’, a charity that runs Forest schools for all ages, to run Mother & Toddler and teenage ‘back to nature’ groups.

We have many volunteers from across the community, working with the Job Centre and the ‘Volunteering on prescription’ service; this allows often vulnerable adults in the community to gain work experience and develop their self esteem. In addition to this we welcome Students from across the UK on work placements and study trips, and offer Artist and Musician sabbaticals. We also encourage local people who need facilities to get their own self employment off the ground to discuss their needs with us. Mellowcroft offers a personally tailored rate and where possible offers the space they need for free until they can afford it.

As a Social Enterprise we are funded to offer this charity and community support by ‘Friends of Mellowcroft’ members, retreat users from all over the world and from small events held in the summers. The accommodation offered for those retreats is humble consisting of a small number of reclaimed timber and cedar cabins in shepherd hut style along with a classroom, and treehouse with communal kitchen and lounge.

Internationally acclaimed Cedar Classroom in the Pine Woods with glorious views of the hillside

Mellowcroft offers access to alternative health facilities and practitioners. We make use of the mineral rich natural spring water abundant in the area by preserving the ‘Spa’ heritage of the area.

We welcome input from those with an interest and experience in renewable energy and sustainable practise so that we can be guided to achieve the best possible future for the project.

Mellowcroft does not claim any grants or farming subsidies for the land as we do not believe it is a sustainable way to farm or protect the environment. We are the embodiment of all the European, National, Welsh Assembly and Local Council guidelines for sustainable development and farm diversification – We are ticking every box.

Since buying the smallholding in 2006 we’ve welcomed regular visits from a Planning Officer who noted the improvements and modest changes we were making to what was a derelict smallholding, and encouraged us with his comments. In the absence of any advice or formal notification to the contrary - we believed we were working within planning law, surely we would have been told if we were not.

So what’s the problem?

We are currently being driven out by our County Council with behaviour that has already been deemed “unreasonable” by the Planning Inspectorate.

It seems we were misled over a period of 8 years by the Council as in December 2013 came the 1st Enforcement Notice.

That was it - no prior warning, no letter or phone call to discuss any issues or concerns – just the Enforcement Notice formally accusing us of criminal development and giving just 9 months to demolish everything and get off the land.  What was worse, no-one was available to meet in the Council office till mid-January, which gave us just three days to make an Appeal before the deadline to do so would expire.

We pleaded for time to submit a planning application so that the council could ‘regulate’ the site but were refused. Instead - we were advised that ‘perhaps, if we claimed to be travellers, we could avoid eviction”!

Our appeal to the Planning Inspectorate resulted in our case being scheduled for a Public Inquiry in October 2014 however, just two weeks before we would have the chance to have our say – The County Council withdrew the Enforcement notice and cancelled the Inquiry. The Welsh Assembly granted us a partial award of costs – which the County Council is ‘vigorously’ opposing despite it being conceded ‘that it was not expedient to serve the Enforcement Notice in the first instance’.

You would think then that we were safe – you couldn’t be more wrong!

Despite taking the first opportunity to submit a full and, if we do say so ourselves, an impressive planning application the County Council have Enforced against us again, Twice! Both served on the same date in spite of having our application in their hands at the time.

In fact it’s the same Planning officer that got the previous Enforcement so very ‘wrong’ that has served the 2 new Enforcements! They are also the very same person who is assessing, in a supposedly unbiased way, our planning application – a complete conflict of interest if ever there was one.

Further to this, the very same planning officer arrived unannounced at Mellowcroft just a few weeks ago to assess our planning application and brought a Police escort – we feel strongly that this was a stunt to tarnish Mellowcroft’s reputation.

This same planning officer demanded a ‘Great Crested Newt’ survey for our planning application; warning us of a potential prison sentence if we so much a shone a torch on the wildlife pool, whilst simultaneously demanding that we fill in the same pools in the Enforcement Notices!

So you can see that the unreasonable behaviour highlighted by the Planning Inspectorate and The Welsh Assembly has not abated.

A tiny new resident of the Wildlife pool

We have tried to discuss our planning application with the Planning Dept, like any other applicant who pays for this service from their council. We are told time and again that we can have that opportunity in our appeal! They show no respect for the democratic process of the public planning committee which should decide our planning application. They have frequently exploited their power and we can only assume that with egg on their face from the previous farce that this is a personal grudge they will not let go.

At no point have we tried to deceive the Planners, or hide any of the work at Mellowcroft. We have welcomed our neighbours, local community and the world to get involved with the project and this welcome has been extended to us in return. Our local community and district council recently voted to approve our planning application due to huge local support and our commitment to the social, environmental and economic benefits.

We were advised, after a meeting to discuss our concerns with Powys Chief Executive, that if a formal planning application to regularise existing development was made “it is likely that the council will not oppose such a measure where an appropriate planning application is submitted”. It would appear from this advice that he was unaware of the intentions of his own Planning officer.

What’s the situation now?

Despite our best efforts to submit an appropriate planning application we have now been served a further two enforcement notices which are currently held in abeyance by the Planning Inspectorate until the application has been decided upon. As the aforementioned Council planning officer has constantly alluded to the imminent refusal of our application we are preparing for another Public Inquiry.

Orchids now flourish in our wildlife meadows

What’s needed?

Quite frankly - we need financial support to save ‘Mellowcroft’ and the tireless work that is done here to protect the natural world and our community for generations to come.  Our project has suffered greatly under the threat of demolishment and it’s a battle which we have poured our heart and soul into.

Whilst the help we have had so far has been invaluable in keeping us in the fight; it is now time to hire a legal professional to represent us and bring this desperate affair to a sensible conclusion for us and our community; who are devastated by the impending loss of the valuable asset we provide.

If we are to have any hope of success; we need to raise enough money to hire a suitable Barrister to present our case, expose the council’s abuse of power and the factual error in their action against us. 

The council have made it clear in email correspondence that they do not respect our opinions, evidence or arguments as they do not believe we are ‘qualified’ to question them, hence the need for professional representation.

Extensive inquiries have shown that something in the region of £15,000 will be needed to hire a Barrister with the qualities and experience to take the case on. They will need to be able to see through the complex maze of evidence, planning policy and legislation.

Added to this, we estimate £5000 will see us through while we try to balance running Mellowcroft at the same time as this incredibly trying legal battle. £5000 will pay for 400 man-hours and travel costs for 4 key staff members. With this extra support we can maintain the important service we provide for the charities, volunteers and community in the midst of these nightmarish circumstances.

How can you help?

By donating to this crowd funding appeal:

You will help us to protect the valuable heritage of this ancient smallholding and enable us to continue to support our community through Mellowcroft’s social enterprise promise.

You will help us to prove that sensitive, sustainable businesses can exist in harmony with the natural environment while improving the social & economic viability of small rural communities.

You will help to protect the vulnerable biodiversity and the natural landscape for generations to come.

You will help us to protect the land for use by local charities, volunteers and community groups, and to continue promoting Off-grid low–impact lifestyles and permaculture.

You will help to preserve the opportunity for anyone who feels the need to retreat from the modern world and reconnect with a simpler, more wholesome way of life. Here, they can do so in a safe, natural and holistic environment and at an affordable rate.

Please give what you can to help our cause – we fight not just for ourselves and our home but for a project that is genuinely beneficial to many.

Every penny counts so please pledge something – County Councils should be held to account when they take liberties with their authority over the public – this is the chance for you to get involved in doing just that.

Isolated we are vulnerable – together we are strong.

Kevin McLoud relaxing in the open air wood-fired baths


Our promise to you

We promise to use the funds for the purposes of hiring a Barrister and additional staff to fight the Planning Authorities ill-conceived course of action

We promise to publish receipts for every penny spent and that any funds left over after this defence will be donated to Powys Young Carers and Local Roots ‘forest school’, the two charities that Mellowcroft actively supports at present.

We promise to publish all documentation associated with the Planning Application and Enforcement Appeal and ensure that the process and outcome are accessible to as many as possible.

We promise to publish the date, time and venue for the Public Inquiry.  We aim to accommodate those who travel to support us from further afield.

We promise to stream the public Inquiry for those who cannot attend ‘LIVE’ on the internet and publish the link on our website and social media pages.

We promise to continue our commitment to sustainable, environmentally sensitive land management; recognising the centuries of back breaking input from generations of smallholders.

We promise to make it our mission to get government recognition of the need to protect all historical small-holdings by way of ‘section 106 agreements’ to safeguard our cultural heritage. This will allow ordinary people, through appropriate diversification, to secure the economic viability of the land and rebuild their local rural communities for many centuries to come.

We are already in dialogue with the Welsh Assembly about the effect of inflexible planning departments on the economic regeneration and overall future of rural communities.

We aim to promote an online network of rural communities, towns and villages to enable the sharing information and strategy to change things for the better - for the future.


Fudge - our welsh hill pony - in his element on the fellside despite the winters chill.
Thank you for reading our story and for your support in our time of need.
story_txt:
Who are we?

We are Eddie
and Kim McIntosh and our 2 year old daughter Eloise. We own, manage and run Mellowcroft
Natural Holistic Retreat. 
Mellowcroft is an off–grid, low impact social enterprise in
Mid Wales on an ancient 12 acre smallholding.
Alongside horticulture we offer calming retreats for those
seeking to escape the hectic pace of modern life and reconnect with the
environment. We have community allotment space for individuals and local social
groups. 
Every year we offer free respite retreats for around 40
teenagers from a local charity known as Powys Young Carers, as their name
suggests they are all full time carers for their own parents and siblings, they
rely upon their time with us to recharge their batteries and get the
opportunity to just be kids for a while.
We manage the land to encourage wildlife habitat and
biodiversity with a commitment to identifying, protecting and promoting native
species of flora and fauna. We work with the advice/support of the Woodland
Trust and Radnorshire Wildlife Association and have regular visits to record
the species on site and help it flourish. 
Our management of the land has protected several ancient
species of insect, one of which appears in the ‘Red Book’.
We offer free space to ‘Local Roots’, a charity that runs Forest
schools for all ages, to run Mother & Toddler and teenage ‘back to nature’
groups.
We have many volunteers from across the community, working
with the Job Centre and the ‘Volunteering on prescription’ service; this allows
often vulnerable adults in the community to gain work experience and develop
their self esteem. In addition to this we welcome Students from across the UK
on work placements and study trips, and offer Artist and Musician sabbaticals. We
also encourage local people who need facilities to get their own self
employment off the ground to discuss their needs with us. Mellowcroft offers a personally
tailored rate and where possible offers the space they need for free until they
can afford it.
As a Social Enterprise we are funded to offer this charity
and community support by ‘Friends of Mellowcroft’ members, retreat users from
all over the world and from small events held in the summers. The accommodation
offered for those retreats is humble consisting of a small number of reclaimed
timber and cedar cabins in shepherd hut style along with a classroom, and treehouse with communal kitchen and
lounge.

Internationally acclaimed Cedar Classroom in the Pine Woods with glorious views of the hillside

Mellowcroft offers access to alternative health facilities
and practitioners. We make use of the mineral rich natural spring water
abundant in the area by preserving the ‘Spa’ heritage of the area. 
We welcome input from those with an interest and experience
in renewable energy and sustainable practise so that we can be guided to
achieve the best possible future for the project.
Mellowcroft does not claim any grants or farming subsidies
for the land as we do not believe it is a sustainable way to farm or protect
the environment. We are the embodiment of all the European, National, Welsh
Assembly and Local Council guidelines for sustainable development and farm
diversification – We are ticking every box.
Since buying the smallholding in 2006 we’ve welcomed regular
visits from a Planning Officer who noted the improvements and modest changes we
were making to what was a derelict smallholding, and encouraged us with his
comments. In the absence of any advice or formal notification to the contrary -
we believed we were working within planning law, surely we would have been told
if we were not. 
So what’s the problem?
We are currently being driven out by our County Council with
behaviour that has already been deemed “unreasonable” by the Planning
Inspectorate.
It seems we were misled over a period of 8 years by the Council
as in December 2013 came the 1st Enforcement Notice.
That was it
- no prior warning, no letter or phone call to discuss any issues or concerns –
just the Enforcement Notice formally accusing us of criminal development and
giving just 9 months to demolish everything and get off the land.  What was worse, no-one was available to meet
in the Council office till mid-January, which gave us just three days to make
an Appeal before the deadline to do so would expire. 
We pleaded for time to submit a planning application so that
the council could ‘regulate’ the site but were refused. Instead - we were
advised that ‘perhaps, if we claimed to be travellers, we could avoid eviction”!
Our appeal to the Planning Inspectorate resulted in our case
being scheduled for a Public Inquiry in October 2014 however, just two weeks
before we would have the chance to have our say – The County Council withdrew
the Enforcement notice and cancelled the Inquiry. The Welsh Assembly granted us
a partial award of costs – which the County Council is ‘vigorously’ opposing
despite it being conceded ‘that it was not expedient to serve the Enforcement
Notice in the first instance’.
You would think then that we were safe – you couldn’t be
more wrong!
Despite taking the first opportunity to submit a full and,
if we do say so ourselves, an impressive planning application the County
Council have Enforced against us again, Twice! Both served on the same date in spite
of having our application in their hands at the time. 
In fact it’s the same Planning officer that got the previous
Enforcement so very ‘wrong’ that has served the 2 new Enforcements! They are
also the very same person who is assessing, in a supposedly unbiased way, our planning
application – a complete conflict of interest if ever there was one. 
Further to this, the very same planning officer arrived unannounced
at Mellowcroft just a few weeks ago to assess our planning application and
brought a Police escort – we feel strongly that this was a stunt to tarnish
Mellowcroft’s reputation. 
This same planning officer demanded a ‘Great Crested Newt’
survey for our planning application; warning us of a potential prison sentence if
we so much a shone a torch on the wildlife pool, whilst simultaneously
demanding that we fill in the same pools in the Enforcement Notices!
So you can see that the unreasonable behaviour highlighted
by the Planning Inspectorate and The Welsh Assembly has not abated.




A tiny new resident of the Wildlife pool 

We have tried to discuss our planning application
with the Planning Dept, like any other applicant who pays for this service from their
council. We are told time and again that we can have that opportunity in our appeal!
They show no respect for the democratic process of the public planning committee
which should decide our planning application. They have frequently exploited their power and we can only assume that with egg on their face from the
previous farce that this is a personal grudge they will not let go.
At no point have we tried to deceive the Planners, or hide
any of the work at Mellowcroft. We have welcomed our neighbours, local
community and the world to get involved with the project and this welcome has
been extended to us in return. Our local community and district council
recently voted to approve our planning application due to huge local support
and our commitment to the social, environmental and economic benefits.
We were advised, after a meeting to discuss our concerns with
Powys Chief Executive, that if a formal planning application to regularise
existing development was made “it is likely that the council will not oppose
such a measure where an appropriate planning application is submitted”. It would
appear from this advice that he was unaware of the intentions of his own Planning officer. 
What’s the situation now?
Despite our best efforts to submit an appropriate planning
application we have now been served a further two enforcement notices which are
currently held in abeyance by the Planning Inspectorate until the application
has been decided upon. As the aforementioned Council planning officer has
constantly alluded to the imminent refusal of our application we are preparing
for another Public Inquiry.


Orchids now flourish in our wildlife meadows

What’s needed?
Quite frankly - we need financial support to save
‘Mellowcroft’ and the tireless work that is done here to protect the natural
world and our community for generations to come.  Our project has suffered greatly under the threat
of demolishment and it’s a battle which we have poured our heart and soul into.

Whilst the help we have had so far has been invaluable in
keeping us in the fight; it is now time to hire a legal professional to
represent us and bring this desperate affair to a sensible conclusion for us
and our community; who are devastated by the impending loss of the valuable
asset we provide.
If we are to have any hope of success; we need to raise enough
money to hire a suitable Barrister to present our case, expose the council’s abuse
of power and the factual error in their action against us.  
The council have made it clear in email correspondence that
they do not respect our opinions, evidence or arguments as they do not believe
we are ‘qualified’ to question them, hence the need for professional
representation.
Extensive inquiries have shown that something in the region of £15,000 will be needed to
hire a Barrister with the qualities and experience to take the case on. They will need to be able to see
through the complex maze of evidence, planning policy and legislation.

Added to this, we estimate £5000 will see us through while we try to
balance running Mellowcroft at the same time as this incredibly trying legal
battle. £5000 will pay for 400 man-hours and travel costs for 4 key staff
members. With this extra support we can maintain the important service
we provide for the charities, volunteers and community in the midst of
these nightmarish circumstances. 



How
can you help?
By
donating to this crowd funding appeal: 
You
will help us to protect the valuable heritage of this ancient smallholding and
enable us to continue to support our community through Mellowcroft’s social
enterprise promise.
You
will help us to prove that sensitive, sustainable businesses can exist in
harmony with the natural environment while improving the social & economic
viability of small rural communities.
You
will help to protect the vulnerable biodiversity and the natural landscape for
generations to come.
You
will help us to protect the land for use by local charities, volunteers and
community groups, and to continue promoting Off-grid low–impact lifestyles
and permaculture.
You
will help to preserve the opportunity for anyone who feels the need
to retreat from the modern world and reconnect with a simpler, more wholesome
way of life. Here, they can do so in a safe, natural and holistic environment and at an
affordable rate.
Please
give what you can to help our cause – we fight not just for ourselves and our
home but for a project that is genuinely beneficial to many.
Every
penny counts so please pledge something – County Councils should be held to
account when they take liberties with their authority over the public – this is
the chance for you to get involved in doing just that.
Isolated
we are vulnerable – together we are strong. 


Kevin McLoud relaxing in the open air wood-fired baths
Our promise to you
We promise to use the funds for the purposes of hiring a
Barrister and additional staff to fight the Planning Authorities ill-conceived
course of action
We promise to publish receipts for every penny spent and
that any funds left over after this defence will be donated to Powys Young
Carers and Local Roots ‘forest school’, the two charities that Mellowcroft
actively supports at present. 
We promise to publish all documentation associated with the
Planning Application and Enforcement Appeal and ensure that the process and
outcome are accessible to as many as possible. 
We promise to publish the date, time and venue for the
Public Inquiry.  We aim to accommodate those
who travel to support us from further afield.
We promise to stream the public Inquiry for those who cannot
attend ‘LIVE’ on the internet and publish the link on our website and social
media pages.
We promise to continue our commitment to sustainable,
environmentally sensitive land management; recognising the centuries of back
breaking input from generations of smallholders.
We promise to make it our mission to get government
recognition of the need to protect all historical small-holdings by way of
‘section 106 agreements’ to safeguard our cultural heritage. This will allow ordinary
people, through appropriate diversification, to secure the economic viability
of the land and rebuild their local rural communities for many centuries to
come.
We are already in dialogue with the Welsh Assembly about the
effect of inflexible planning departments on the economic regeneration and
overall future of rural communities. 
We aim to promote an online network of rural communities,
towns and villages to enable the sharing information and strategy to change
things for the better - for the future.

Fudge - our welsh hill pony - in his element on the fellside despite the winters chill.Thank you for reading
our story and for your support in our time of need.

story:
Short summary

My name is Naomi Whitfield and I am a year 11 student from Linton Village College, Cambridgeshire. I have signed up with Camps International to go on a volunteer expedition to Borneo next summer after I have taken my GCSEs. I will be going on a four-week quest, living and working with local people to do community development work, environmental projects and wildlife conservation. It also includes a personal challenge: a four day jungle trek when I will traverse the jungle and its natural obstacles, survive the humidity and sleep in my own hammock! Your contribution will help me get one step nearer to this amazing once in a life time trip, during which I will work my hardest in Borneo to improve social development of rural village communities and environmental protection of the rainforest, at the same time as learning many life skills.

Expedition to Borneo

This journey is soooo important to me, I am really excited and a little scared too.

The trip will be hard work, as will my fundraising as I am the only student from LVC going. To solely raise the funds (nearly £4000) seemed a huge task when I started fundraising 10 months ago, but with all the work my mum and I have done so far the end is in sight. This campaign will go a huge way to helping me reach my goal.

As a volunteer I will be in a living in village camps that are built locally, staffed locally and  supplied locally. The camps act as hubs from which Camps International develops and sustains community, wildlife and environmental programmes.

During the trip I will develop many important life skills such as budgeting money, cooking for a group and myself, and learning true independence. I am nervous about getting home sick and hurting myself or getting ill while away from home. I am hoping I will quickly get used to the temperature change, remember to drink lots of water, and if I meet a poisonous animal I will know how to avoid it!

I will need to take lots of equipment with me for the trip, but some will be left for the villagers to benefit from when I have gone. While it is less for me to carry home, it also means I can continue contributing to the community after my trip.

For the expedition itself, I will be joining another school. I am looking forward to working with them and making new friends.

Objectives achieved in Borneo

The core objectives of this expedition are to undertake projects in order to:

• Raise the educational standards of developing communities within a rural district of Borneo

• Raise the living standards of developing communities, within a rural district of Borneo

• Assist with ongoing wildlife conservation programmes to preserve biodiversity and protect vulnerable habitats.

How you can help

I would be extremely grateful for any contribution you can make towards my fundraising. Your contribution will mean new trees will be planted in the rainforest, children will be taught English and construction of community buildings in the village will be a step closer to completion. If you could spread the word of my fundraising to your friends, family, and colleagues that would be really wonderful.

Thank you
