story:
Hello, my name is Jerry Stancill. I grew up in the Bay Area, and I have lived here all my life. In 2011, I earned my Bachelor of Science Degree in Criminal Justice, from Union Institute and University. Prior to earning my B.S. Degree, I worked as a police officer from 1998-2007, and was promoted to the rank of Police Sergeant in October 2007. I retired from the police department in January of 2010. While working in law enforcement, I had experience in Patrol, SWAT, & Investigations. I was assigned to the Criminal Investigations Division as a School Resource Officer and a Juvenile Sexual Assault Investigator. I remained in the Juvenile Division for seven out of my eleven years.

One of the most rewarding moments in my career, were the years I was assigned to the Juvenile Division. I had the sad, but honorable opportunity to work with hundreds, if not thousands of at-risk, missing/exploited children, abused children, high school drop-outs, victims of suspected crimes, teen suspects, who were suspected of committing crimes and much more. Lack of education and guidance whether from a parent, family member, teacher, police, or the court system and much more were common themes amongst most of the youth.

I was able to recognize and deal with most of their issues. My mother was on welfare and trying to feed three older siblings and I. Sadly; my father was shot and killed by a police officer. In 1998, I dropped out of high school and found myself living as a transient for over a year. My story can go on for a while, so we can revisit that another day and time. I was later blessed after receiving support from people in the working community. From that, I gained confidence and structure. I went in to earn my G.E.D., Associate’s of Science Degree in Administration of Justice, and as I mentioned earlier, my Bachelor of Science Degree in Criminal Justice.  I became a product of that “No Child Left Behind.” 

With my life and law enforcement experience, I wanted to make a different in a child’s life. From this passion, I created “M.A.K.E.” “M.A.K.E.” is an eWaste recycling service for foster teens, at-risks teens, and for teens who are simply under privileged to work. “M.A.K.E” will set out to collect computers, laptops, monitors, TV’s, and cable wire. I have ensured that all usable resources are recycled items that we collect will be redistributed through one of our environmentally friendly local e-Cycling facilities to help mitigate any impact on the environment.

Our goal at “M.A.K.E.” is to assist teens in building a foundation of honesty and trust, and to develop a commitment to protecting the environment. Because I believe in higher education and the “No Child Left Behind,” each student will be required to further their education to remain in the “M.A.K.E.” program. Each student will have the responsibility of obtaining their high school diploma, their G.E.D., and or an Associate’s Degree from a community college.

For students that have not earned their G.E.D, “M.A.K.E.” will cover 100% cost for our students to prepare and take the exam. The student must have been in, and remain in the program for no less than six months, with minimal missed days collecting eWaste.

For students, that have earned their high school diploma and cannot afford community college, “We Foster” will guide our students on how to apply for school and after the student has remained in the program for at least one year, “M.A.K.E.” will cover a percentage of the cost for our students to attend community college. The proceeds will come from our diligence of collecting, and or receiving items to recycle. 

Our goal today, is to receive electronic donations, get financial help to purchase marketing products, a website, uniform shirts, protective wear, delivery/pick-up trucks, lease a building, purchase educational tools, & purchase the proper eWaste permits from the city. Become a part of the “No Child Left Behind” movement.

Sincerely,

Jerry Stancill

story:
It'd be pretty awesome if you'd "share" the video with a comment about  ASA

"With so much good farmland disappearing, 
where are people going to get their food from in the future?" 
- Joan McArthur-Fiske

Housing developments don’t need good soils to grow. Food does. 
How can you argue with that?

About Us 

The Agricultural Stewardship Association (ASA) is a private, community supported non-profit land trust conserving valuable farmland in Washington and Rensselaer counties for future generations. We help landowners who want to protect their productive land so that it remains available for farming. To date, ASA has protected 15,443 acres on 99 farms. 

The Impact

This summer, in honor of her ancestors (Janette McArthur, Charlie Sauert and their son, Malcolm), Joan McArthur-Fiske hopes to protect the McArthur-Sauert Farm in the Bald Mountain area of the town of Greenwich. This historic farm, a beautiful landmark in Washington County, has been in agricultural production since before the Civil War. The farm was a successful dairy operation for most of the 100 years it has been owned by Joan’s family.

   

The farm’s 159 acres of large cultivated fields near the Batten Kill contain some of the richest agricultural soils in the town. This irreplaceable resource now serves primarily as support land for a local dairy operation. Unfortunately, the McArthur-Sauert Farm is at high risk of being converted to non-agricultural use if not protected. Its close proximity to Saratoga County, extensive road frontage and flat, well drained soils make the property susceptible to development.

       

When Joan approached ASA, she told stories about what the farm meant to her family and what it has come to mean to her. Joan understands the value of good soils: “With so much good farmland disappearing, where are people going to get their food from in the future?” Housing developments don’t need good soils to grow. Food does. How can you argue with that?

Joan is determined that her land stay in farm production. With the funds she will receive in return for conserving her farm, she will start the restoration of the beautiful configuration of roadside 19th Century barns back to their original condition.

To Joan, like so many others, it seems a simple gift, but one that will be enjoyed forever by generations we will never meet. Think about it: conserving land is one of the few lasting and permanent effects you can have on this world. ASA has raised the majority of the funds for this project and Joan is generously donating a portion of her development rights, but we still need to raise the remaining $7,000. We’re counting on help from people who care about where their food comes from to help make this project happen. Please consider making a donation today to protect this treasure.

story:
Short Summary

In respect of “Earth Day” we have organized a non-profit plan of reforestation to recover the devastated natural areas in Gorski Kotar. The event is called "FORESTS ARE LIFE”, and is planned for Saturday, April 13th

Our goal is to put people from all walks of life, ages and beliefs into one group with the same mission  to promote :

  • Unity of community and the understanding of its purpose 
  • A sustainable way of life in symbiosis with nature
  • Environmental protection
  • Education for all generations

Trees help sustain life by absorbing CO2, creating oxygen, providing shade, protecting soil from erosion, safeguarding ground water, and guarding biodiversity. Each tree planted captures 1 ton of C02 by the time it reaches maturity.

What We Need & What You Get

We are seeking to have well over 500+ volunteers. We need about 4000 EUR to reach our goal. That money will be used  to sustain the volunteers. We're providing them free drinks, and lunch. We are providing transportation for all students and teachers to the planting site. 

After the hard work, we have organized a live concert in the town square for the community, as a way to thank everyone involved. 

We would also like to hire a camera man to capture this special day so that we can create a video and share it all around the world to further inspire people to be the change!

The Impact

The SUCCESS of this non-profit action is to encourage all generations and people of different financial frameworks to work together to rebuild the forest areas affected by natural disasters. Through education, and an understanding of the environment where we live together, we want to do our best to preserve and improve this area for future generations.

During the planting, we have an expert coming to teach the volunteers about how to better sustain our forests, and the impact of what they're doing that day will have on their environment.

It's so important for the little ones watching us to see the importance of respecting nature and that we can all work together as a community for the better of the world around us. 

Risks & Challenges

The risks and challenges we face are quite clear. We may overestimate, or even underestimate the amount of volunteers that sign up. We may not raise enough funds to be able to provide them with everything we hope to provide them with. In the case scenario with rain, we'll postpone the whole event for two weeks. But we have a firm plan in place for these types of situations, and we will overcome any obstacles!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has the means to donate, and we definitely understand that. If this is you, there are still plenty of ways you can help us get to our goal! 

Please share our campaign with all of your friends.

If you live in Croatia, you are more than welcome to join our growing team of volunteers on April 13th.

#bethechange #forestsarelife #croatianway

story:
Last month, I joined hundreds of brave climate warriors, including 30 young Pacific Islanders in the Port of Newcastle - the biggest coal port in the world - and blocked coal ships for the day in plastic canoes.

When we heard the cry of the shell horn from our Pacific Island leader, I took to the water with my new friend Nelly from Tonga and paddled out into the shipping lane. It wasn't long before police circled our boat, yelled profanities at us and capsized us, and hauled into the police boat.

Everyone was shocked by the way police treated the Warriors. They took away our oars, they broke our boats and taunted us - but they could not take away our warrior spirit. We stopped 10 coal ships from entering and leaving the harbour that day, and sent a powerful message to the coal industry - their days are numbered, we will fight until we win.

Fast forward to 2 weeks later when I got a fine in the post for $500. This came as a surprise to me because the police made no mention of it in the boat. This totally sucks because I can't really afford to pay it.

I know I have a strong community who've got my back, it would be awesome (if you've got the means) to have your support to help me pay off this fine. Any additional funds will be donated to 350 Pacific because I love them.

I'll continue fighting for climate justice so that our Pacific Island brothers and sisters do not drown in a fossil-fuel addicted world.

story:
The scoop

OK - you pick up after your dog 100% of the time using a plastic bag then throw it in the trash.  Truly commendable!  But do you ever get the feeling that that trashing the poop isn't the coolest environmental move?  As you pitch that parcel in the bin, do you wonder if it might have some purpose, like enriching the soil and helping a flower grow?

Our professional composting process "upcycles" dog waste into Doggone Good Compost, a soil amendment that's meets EPA standards for safety, smells great (really!) and provides a feast of nutrients for plants.  What is "upcycling?"

"Recycling" changes or reconditions material that is no longer useful back into the system for further use.  "Upcycling" transforms it into something more valuable than it was at the start.  An upcycled material not only pays back, but pays back with interest!

The scope

There's no getting around it - we're talking about upcycling smelly stuff.  You don't want to mess with it any more than you have to.  And there's SO MUCH OF IT!

You take it.  No, you take it.

Nobody wants it but US.  Yes, US.  We are Colorado business owners -- a pet waste scooper, a professional composter and a garden soils wholesaler.  We have teamed up to collect loads of the stuff and turn it into safe, high-quality compost.  We want to change the way communities dispose of dog waste and how people feel about using pet waste to nurture plants.

Tall order, we know.  Let's look at some key facts.

A recent San Francisco waste audit found that 4-5% of the city's residential waste is dog poop.   If we're ever going to reach zero waste, we've got to reduce carbon paw prints.  Traditional composters won't accept dog waste and large scale flushing would overwhelm sewage treatment plants.  Trash cans are our only community option.

Instead of streaming dog waste into a sealed landfill where it is preserved for posterity and reeks methane gas, why not  send it back to the earth?   Composting is an elegant solution! 

And what's with all these plastic poop bags?  Manufacturers are actually creating bags to make it easier to entomb and mummify dog poop.  Recycling old bags for a dumb purpose is also pretty lame.  Wouldn't the world be a better place if we got rid of plastic bags altogether, used scoopers or certified compostable bags and turned this waste stream into a soil amendment?  That's what our clients do.

Dog meets plant

You've seen all those doggie bare spots on lawns and ruined landscapes.  When we think of dog poop we think of brown plants.  But what if dogs could help green up plants?  They can if their raw waste is mixed with a good bulking material, turned  so that air, heat and microbes work their magic, and aged to produce a mild, fragrant compost.

Our compost has a balanced pH and a smorgasbord of plant nutrients.  We tested doggie compost against premium commercial brands  and found that ours is pretty potent stuff!  Check out the video to see how Doggone Good Compost produces fast-growing, healthy plants.

Our next step

We've developed a client base of local raw material "donors" who are dedicated to sustainability.  They include households, dog day cares, dog parks, a veterinarian, an animal shelter, even a bar!

Sit. Stay. Good human.

We experimented for years to find the perfect composting recipe and test marketed finished bagged products at local retail garden centers. 

But if we want this environmentally sustainable product to be financially sustainable, we've got to ramp up production and distribution.  We are customizing a motorized in-vessel compost tumbler with the capacity to process tons of dog waste into a nutrient-rich soil amendment. 

This tumbler can produce 45 cubic yards of compost per week.

Here's how you can help

We'd like to see soils made from local pet waste on retail garden shelves all over the country.  After all, we compost and distribute farm and ranch waste.  Why shouldn't our tons of city pet waste be part of the mix?  These soils should be produced locally using local canine contributions.

To give this pet waste upcycling movement momentum, we will
- turn approximately 100 tons of dog poop into safe, top-quality compost 
- produce 50,000 bags of Doggone Good Potting Soil Mixture
- increase public awareness of disposal and environmental issues
- promote the benefits of our product via savvy marketing
- get our product on track for statewide distribution.

First-year revenue will drive future production.

We'll need to shift a lot of thinking to begin moving this product into the mainstream.  But it's hard to stop an idea that just makes good common sense!

Your contribution will close the recycling loop by taking our product to market.  More important still, you'll  show that a material considered totally useless (scorned and derided...polling badly) can have a higher purpose. 

If you can upcycle dog poop...well then, you can upcycle anything!

Help us start changing minds and hearts with your indiegogo contribution.
story_txt:
The scoopOK - you pick up after your dog 100% of the time using a plastic bag then throw it in the trash.  Truly commendable!  But do you ever get the feeling that that trashing the poop isn't the coolest environmental move?  As you pitch that parcel in the bin, do you wonder if it might have some purpose, like enriching the soil and helping a flower grow?

Our professional composting process "upcycles" dog waste into Doggone Good Compost, a soil amendment that's meets EPA standards for safety, smells great (really!) and provides a feast of nutrients for plants.  What is "upcycling?"
"Recycling" changes or reconditions material that is no longer useful back into the system for further use.  "Upcycling" transforms it into something more valuable than it was at the start.  An upcycled material not only pays back, but pays back with interest!The scope
There's no getting around it - we're talking about upcycling smelly stuff.  You don't want to mess with it any more than you have to.  And there's SO MUCH OF IT!
You take it.  No, you take it.

Nobody wants it but US.  Yes, US.  We are Colorado business owners -- a pet waste scooper, a professional composter and a garden soils wholesaler.  We have teamed up to collect loads of the stuff and turn it into safe, high-quality compost.  We want to change the way communities dispose of dog waste and how people feel about using pet waste to nurture plants.
Tall order, we know.  Let's look at some key facts.
A recent San Francisco waste audit found that 4-5% of the city's residential waste is dog poop.   If we're ever going to reach zero waste, we've got to reduce carbon paw prints.  Traditional composters won't accept dog waste and large scale flushing would overwhelm sewage treatment plants.  Trash cans are our only community option.
Instead of streaming dog waste into a sealed landfill where it is preserved for posterity and reeks methane gas, why not  send it back to the earth?   Composting is an elegant solution!  
And what's with all these plastic poop bags?  Manufacturers are actually creating bags to make it easier to entomb and mummify dog poop.  Recycling old bags for a dumb purpose is also pretty lame.  Wouldn't the world be a better place if we got rid of plastic bags altogether, used scoopers or certified compostable bags and turned this waste stream into a soil amendment?  That's what our clients do.

Dog meets plantYou've seen all those doggie bare spots on lawns and ruined landscapes.  When we think of dog poop we think of brown plants.  But what if dogs could help green up plants?  They can if their raw waste is mixed with a good bulking material, turned  so that air, heat and microbes work their magic, and aged to produce a mild, fragrant compost.Our compost has a balanced pH and a smorgasbord of plant nutrients.  We tested doggie compost against premium commercial brands  and found that ours is pretty potent stuff!  Check out the video to see how Doggone Good Compost produces fast-growing, healthy plants.


Our next step
We've developed a client base of local raw material "donors" who are dedicated to sustainability.  They include households, dog day cares, dog parks, a veterinarian, an animal shelter, even a bar!
Sit. Stay. Good human.
We experimented for years to find the perfect composting recipe and test marketed finished bagged products at local retail garden centers.  
But if we want this environmentally sustainable product to be financially sustainable, we've got to ramp up production and distribution.  We are customizing a motorized in-vessel compost tumbler with the capacity to process tons of dog waste into a nutrient-rich soil amendment. 

This tumbler can produce 45 cubic yards of compost per week.
Here's how you can help


We'd like to see soils made from local pet waste on retail garden shelves all over the country.  After all, we compost and distribute farm and ranch waste.  Why shouldn't our tons of city pet waste be part of the mix?  These soils should be produced locally using local canine contributions.
To give this pet waste upcycling movement momentum, we will- turn approximately 100 tons of dog poop into safe, top-quality compost - produce 50,000 bags of Doggone Good Potting Soil Mixture- increase public awareness of disposal and environmental issues- promote the benefits of our product via savvy marketing- get our product on track for statewide distribution.First-year revenue will drive future production.We'll need to shift a lot of thinking to begin moving this product into the mainstream.  But it's hard to stop an idea that just makes good common sense!
Your contribution will close the recycling loop by taking our product to market.  More important still, you'll  show that a material considered totally useless (scorned and derided...polling badly) can have a higher purpose.  
If you can upcycle dog poop...well then, you can upcycle anything!
Help us start changing minds and hearts with your indiegogo contribution.

story:
Short Summary

Life is tough for a baby sea turtle. Just one out of a thousand turtle hatchlings survives until adulthood. Facing poaching, getting caught in fishing gear, and other threats, and its not surprising that six out of seven species are threatened or endangered. Billion Baby Turtles works to reverse that trend and our goal is to fill the ocean with turtle hatchlings.

With your help, we can save another 10,000 endangered hawksbill sea turtle hatchlings in El Salvador by supporting the great work of the Eastern Pacific Hawksbill Initiative (ICAPO). There are only an estimated 500 nesting female hawksbills along the entire Pacific coast of the America’s but the ICAPO network is working hard to protect one of the most important nesting areas at Jiquilisco Bay by working with local residents to save the eggs and protect the adults from fishing and other threats.

We believe conservation should have concrete outcomes. For every dollar that we raise, we will save at least two turtle hatchlings by providing the funds needed to hire people to patrol nesting beaches, build hatcheries that keep the eggs safe until hatching, and supporting educational programs. Since the project launched in April 2013, we have helped save more than 250,000 hatchlings at ten important turtle nesting beaches in Latin America.

Our stretch goal is $10,000, which if reached, would allow us to fund egg collection programs at the two critical hawksbill nesting areas in the region, which make up 90% of the known nesting of the population. The result would be 20,000 hatchlings saved in Nicaragua and El Salvador, in addition to supporting local residents with important income.

Billion Baby Turtles was founded by two lifelong turtle conservationists, Dr. Wallace J. Nichols and Brad Nahill, who spent years working with community-based conservation programs in Mexico and Costa Rica. This initiative is part of SEE Turtles, a non-profit project that supports sea turtle conservation through travel and education.

Please note: Your donations will go through our sponsor, The Oceanic Society. You will receive an email confirmation once you donate.

What We Need & What You Get

We have a big long-term goal, to put a billion hatchlings into the ocean to help restore sea turtle populations. With your help, we can put a dent in that big goal while helping to support deserving community-based turtle conservation projects around the world. The result will be at least 10,000 hatchlings protected in 2014.

Our goal for this campaign is to raise at least $5,000 which will support efforts to protect one of the most endangered turtle populations in the world, the hawksbill turtles living along the Pacific coast of the America’s. Our partners at the Eastern Pacific Hawksbill Initiative run an inspiring project in El Salvador in a beautiful place called Jiquilisco Bay. Here, a group of former poachers now work to protect the hawksbills by bringing their eggs to hatcheries, where they are protected until they hatch and then released to the ocean.

If we reach our stretch goal of $10,000 raised, we will be able to extend support to the other main hawksbill nesting area in the region, Padre Ramos Estuary. Roughly 90% of the Eastern Pacific hawksbill nest at Padre Ramos or Jiquilisco Bay and this would help to save roughly 20,000 hatchlings in 2015, representing nearly every hatchling produced at these two critically important nesting beaches.

In return for your generosity, we have a huge variety of turtle-themed and eco-friendly perks. We have handmade jewelry (including some made in Costa Rica), reusable water bottles, recycled plastic handbags, and much more. For the real turtle lovers, we have a gift pack with just about every turtley thing you can imagine. Check out our gallery for photos of some of the perks and check back often for new ones that we'll add as the campaign goes on. 

* If we reach our stretch goal, every $50 or higher donor will receive a photo of a hatchling from Nicaragua in addition to their perks and $100 donors and up will receive a framed photo.

The Impact

Healthy oceans and coastal communities need sea turtles. They help to keep prey like jellyfish under control and their nests help stabilize beaches. They help coastal communities by providing a great ecotourism attraction and many indigenous cultures celebrate them. Watching a sea turtle come ashore to lay its eggs is an extraordinary experience that everyone should be able to have.

To date Billion Baby Turtles has provided enough funding to save more than 250,000 hatchlings at 10 important nesting beaches around Latin America. SEE Turtles has provided financial support to protect Eastern Pacific hawksbills since 2011 and to date we have helped to save nearly 50,000 hatchlings at the two most important nesting beaches.

This money will go towards ICAPO’s egg collection program, which pays local residents to monitor the beaches in the sites in El Salvador and Nicaragua. Once a resident finds a turtle, they carefully bring the eggs to hatcheries, where they are reburied and monitored until they hatch. Residents are paid for every egg they bring as well as how many of them hatch, which incentivizes them to take special care of the eggs while transporting them. This program has allowed residents to earn income for protecting the eggs as opposed to selling them on the illegal black market and is a key source of money in areas with high unemployment and low wages. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations are great but aren’t the only way you can help. The best way to help protect sea turtles is by joining one of our volunteer expeditions to Costa Rica, Mexico, Cuba, Nicaragua, or El Salvador. Learn more about these unique experiences at SEEturtles.org.

The more people we reach, the more successful we will be so please help share the word with friends and family, on Facebook and Twitter, by email or dinnertime conversation! Contact us at info@seeturtles.org if you are interested in our referral program, where you can earn perks for recruiting donors to our campaign. Learn more about Billion Baby Turtles here.

story:
Summary

Since 1937 the Michigan United Conservation Clubs, a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization, has been committed to conserving Michigan’s natural resources and protecting its outdoor heritage. 

In 2012, we joined forces with the Michigan Department of Natural Resources to launch the On the Ground (OTG) program, which was honored with Outdoor Life's Open Country Award after just its first year. This outstanding program engages volunteers in the improvement of fish and wildlife habitats throughout the state of Michigan. 

Thanks to a steady growth of volunteers and projects, the program has been able to help even more fish and wildlife habitats. In two years, over 400 volunteers have completed 21 projects across all regions of Michigan.

OTG is about more than just improving fish and wildlife habitat on public lands though; it’s also about education. The program allows the volunteers who invest their time to gain a deeper understanding of the habit needs of fish and wildlife.

What We Need & What You Get

In order for OTG to grow and to ensure our volunteers’ precious time is spent effectively and productively, we need the right equipment.

We need to raise $500 to purchase equipment for volunteers to use when working. We’re specifically looking to purchase a chainsaw (with the necessary safety equipment) and chest waders. Any donation helps us, but if we don't meet our funding goal then we'll purchase as much equipment as the funding allows.

When you donate to the OTG program you'll receive thank you perks from Outdoor Life and MUCC. So you’re able to read about our work the projects you help fund, you can also receive digital subscription to Michigan Out of Doors Magazine!

With your help, we can do even more by making sure those volunteers have the tools and safety equipment they need! Donate today to join the fastest-growing conservation community in Michigan! 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, there are other things you can do. Use the share tools to spread the word about this campaign or sign-up to volunteer at one of our project sites: www.mucc.org/ontheground!

story:
BLUE MIND at the ROM

Wallace J. Nichols, with EVC, Fleming College and ROM Biodiversity presents:    Blue Mind, Wednesday, November 26th, 2014, 6:00-10:00 PM,                                     Bronfman Hall, Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto, Ontario, Canada

Programming will include keynote speaker, Wallace J. Nichols, a video portrait series highlighting water enthusiasts, additional speakers, surprises, and a unique opportunity to (re)connect with your brain on water.

Let us introduce ourselves!

We are a student team of environmental visual communicators (EVC) from Fleming College, passionately advocating for a conversation about Blue Mind: the relationship between your mind and water. With the help of neuroscience, Wallace J. Nichols and ROM Biodiversity, we are hosting a FREE public event, to open the river of communication and share the wave of Blue Mind (and some blue marbles)  with the world.


About Blue Mind:

Blue Mind connects the dots: neuroscience and psychology, nature and conservation, art and science, poetry and practice in profoundly important new ways. The result is an emerging, exciting, fast-growing new field we call Neuroconservation. With new research and more discoveries about "blue space" yet to come.

The early benefits of this inquiry have already influenced public health, education, parenting, business, coastal planning, travel, real estate, sports and recreation, and most importantly restoring and rebuilding our personal, ancient emotional connection with healthy waterways.

Blue Mind helps those working with and for our blue planet to do their jobs better by providing deeper insights and new questions about the science of "our brains on water".

We expand the "ecosystem services" conversation to include the vast array of cognitive and emotional services, values, and benefits offered by clean, healthy waterways.


Blue Mind and You: 

Through artful, cross-disciplinary collaboration, engaging summits, and revolutionary research Blue Mind is reframing the way we think about water and ourselves by inspiring a deeper (re)connection with nature and inventing solutions to personal and global pressing issues.

  • Personal: (Re)discover yourself through neuroscience, exploring the personal connection between your brain and water.

  • Appreciation: Appreciate the full value of water from an emotional, physiological, practical and psychological perspective.

  • Potential: Nurture our own potential, protect waters potential.

Dip your toes, or jump right in! Join the conversation and discover your brain on water at the ROM November 26th!



What we need + what you get:

  • A keynote speaker- The brain behind Blue Mind, we will be bringing in Wallace J. Nichols as our keynote speaker for our event at the ROM November 26th.  

  • A slow motion camera- We rented a slow motion camera for our trailer, to capture a unique take on (re)connecting with water, now we need to cover the costs of the camera.

  • Event marketing/production- Our event is Free to the public and located at the Royal Ontario Museum, a diverse space to engage a broader audience. However like any event, there are some essential production and marketing costs and to fill the gaps we need your help!

  • Website production- We currently have a website for the event, but we don’t want our conversation to end after November 26th. To continue to share what we have created with those beyond the event we need additional funding to keep the website afloat.

You don't have to attend the event to enjoy the perks of donating!

Our exciting list of perks can be found in the column to the right, such as signed copies of the book, VIP access to the keynote speaker, and even an EVC intern for your company! Also, everyone who donates will be recognized in a tribute of gratitude at the event!


*Any additional funds raised will go towards further expanding and sharing the Blue Mind  message through the non-profit LiVBLUE!


About Wallace J. Nichols:

Dr. Wallace "J." Nichols is a scientist, wild water advocate, movement-maker, New York Times bestselling author, and dad. He takes a slow, collaborative approach with leaders in businesses, government, non-profits, and academia to inspire a deeper connection with nature and inventive solutions to pressing issues. Dr. Nichols is also a Research Associate at the California Academy of Sciences and   co-founder of a number of international conservation networks. He has authored and co-authored more than 50 scientific papers and reports and his work has been broadcast on NPR, BBC, PBS, National Geographic and Animal Planet as well as featured in Time, Newsweek, GQ, Outside Magazine, Fast Company, Scientific American and New Scientist, among others.


About EVC:

Positioned at the convergence of science and art, Fleming College's Environmental Visual Communication program is designed to fill a recognized void of individuals who are passionate about environmental issues and stories and who want to effectively engage people who can foster change. The Blue Mind ROM event is our hands-on approach to campaigning. We brainstormed, wrote strategy, curated and co-created this event into life, and we can’t wait to see it come together!


    Join the wave and help us bring this Blue Mind event to life - we couldn't do it without you!


    Thank you for investing your time and learning about our campaign!

    To find out more check out our website!  http://eviscomm.ca/events/bluemind

    For behind the scenes pictures from the trailer check out our gallery!

Join the wave and help us bring this Blue Mind event to life - we couldn't do it without you!

For behind the scenes pictures from the trailer check out our gallery!

story:
Thankyou for landing here! As I'm sure most of you are aware I'm Jess, a 21 year old aspiring marine scientist from Hobart, Tasmania.

I was lucky enough to be accepted into an Ocean Conservation Research Internship program in South Africa in 2015. The three months I'll be spending in South Africa will not only assist me in gaining momentum as an advocate for healthy ocean ecosystems and marine life, it will provide me with crucial experience and knowledge in this field beyond what I would undertake as an undergraduate student. The internship will include involvement in a dedicated ocean conservation research program, providing education about oceans to South African school children whilst encouraging them to make positive choices and changes for the environment and finally assisting in hands on Great White Shark research and public awareness campaigns.  

I am greatly passionate about this cause for a number of reasons. Perhaps the most important reason to human beings is that the health of life on land runs in direct correlation with the health of oceans globally. Every second breath we take comes from the sea! As the legendary Sylvia Earle put it; “People ask: Why should I care about the ocean? Because the ocean is the cornerstone of earth's life support system, it shapes climate and weather. It holds most of life on earth. 97% of earth's water is there. It's the blue heart of the planet — we should take care of our heart. It's what makes life possible for us. We still have a really good chance to make things better than they are. They won't get better unless we take the action and inspire others to do the same thing. No one is without power. Everybody has the capacity to do something.” 

Okay, now I'm starting to waffle! Basically, this fund is to assist in paying for my flights to and from South Africa. I was hoping to entirely fund this experience myself and was very reluctant to ask for donations, however, that may have been more than a little ambitious! I would be so grateful for any contribution however large or small! Don't forget to claim a gift in return for your support, they're down the right hand side of the page! 

Thankyou so much to Petra & Greg from Bonorong and Shae & Matthew from Pollen Tea Room for really generously donating some gifts for me to provide to my supporters. I plan to put my newly gained knowledge and experience to good work upon arrival back in Hobart.  I've attached a relevant video that briefly touches on why this is such a crucial cause (and an attempt to spice this page up a bit). 

Thankyou so so much,

J.
story_txt:
Thankyou for landing here! As I'm sure most of you are
aware I'm Jess, a 21 year old aspiring marine scientist from Hobart, Tasmania.
I was lucky enough to be accepted into an Ocean Conservation Research Internship program in South Africa in 2015. The three
months I'll be spending in South Africa will not only assist me in gaining momentum as
an advocate for healthy ocean ecosystems and marine life, it will provide me with crucial experience and knowledge in this field beyond what I would undertake as
an undergraduate student. The internship will include involvement in a
dedicated ocean conservation research program, providing education about oceans
to South African school children whilst encouraging them to make positive
choices and changes for the environment and finally assisting in hands on Great
White Shark research and public awareness campaigns.  
I am greatly passionate about this cause for a
number of reasons. Perhaps the most important reason to human beings is that the
health of life on land runs in direct correlation with the
health of oceans globally. Every second breath we take comes from the sea! As
the legendary Sylvia Earle put it; “People ask: Why should I care about the
ocean? Because the ocean is the cornerstone of earth's life support system, it
shapes climate and weather. It holds most of life on earth. 97% of earth's
water is there. It's the blue heart of the planet — we should take care of our
heart. It's what makes life possible for us. We still have a really good chance
to make things better than they are. They won't get better unless we take the
action and inspire others to do the same thing. No one is without power.
Everybody has the capacity to do something.” 
Okay, now I'm starting to waffle!
Basically, this fund is to assist in paying for my flights to and from South
Africa. I was hoping to entirely fund this experience myself and was very
reluctant to ask for donations, however, that may have been more than a little
ambitious! I would be so grateful for any contribution however large or small! Don't forget to claim a gift in return for your support, they're down the right hand side of the page! Thankyou
so much to Petra & Greg from Bonorong and Shae & Matthew from Pollen
Tea Room for really generously donating some gifts for me to provide to my
supporters. I plan to put my newly gained knowledge and experience to good work
upon arrival back in Hobart.  I've attached a relevant video that
briefly touches on why this is such a crucial cause (and an attempt to spice
this page up a bit). 
Thankyou so so much,
J.

story:
Loam is an environmental arts magazine dedicated to promoting the work of pioneering individuals and organizations in the realm of sustainability. We see creativity and sustainability as symbiotic. Our hope is that in illuminating inventive responses to environmental issues, we can help these movements take root. So often, the doom and gloom approach to climate change makes people immobile: we can start to think why bother? Loam believes that meaningful change stems from a place of positivity. When we see examples of others making a difference, we are similarly inspired to adopt ecologically conscious practices. In this way, Loam is a collaborative space for cultivating sustainability practices but it’s also a playful space, a platform for profiling all the good stuff that’s growing in our community.

Right now, it's just the two of us (Kate and Nicole)! The funds that we raise from this campaign will go directly toward developing our online platform. We intend to use any financial support to cover travel costs, carbon offsets, and publication expenses. This campaign is integral to our ability to reach out to the many incredible people that are a part of the environmental movement. Our hope is that by Autumn 2015, we will be able to cultivate enough content and connections to produce our first printed magazine--just in time for the harvest season.

story:
WHO

We are a hip-hop band with an active interest in sustainability and using our music to elevate awareness of serious environmental issues and engage our fanbase to take positive social action.

Our new video ‘This Earth Is F**ked’ (shot at Vauxhall City Farm) - https://youtu.be/RuELL1fE3rc - is not only a ballad of rage, comedy and genuine concern, but a rallying cry to step up, combine efforts, and make a real difference.

We have released this video to coincide with World Environment day 2020 and the launch of this project, Too Many Trees. With your support, we hoping to plant at least 10,000 trees, with a minimum target of 1,000 this November.

The more we raise though, the more we can plant. The sky is the limit, so help us out and let's plant a damn forest! You can literally join in!

 

WHY?

Unless you’re head has been buried in the warm soil, you will be fully aware that the earth is pretty f**ked right about now and we’re not talking about the pandemic.

Despite a record drop in CO2 emissions in 2020 (predicted to be between 4-8%, thanks lockdown), the science tells us that an average reduction of 7.6% is required every year from 2020-2030 to basically not spark off uncontrollable climate madness.

We’re talking worldwide extreme weather, famine, mass-extinction and war. So no biggy guys! 

We’re all humans and our biology dictates we prioritise immediate threats. But as thousands of people are now screaming along with us – climate change is now an immediate threat and we have to act NOW.

 

WHAT WE'RE DOING

'But you two just make Hip-hop music, what are you on about!?' You may ask.

Well, we really (really) give a shit about the environment and always have. One of us has a masters degree in sustainability (bet you didn’t know that). Bottom line though, we want to make a direct impact.

What’s more, we know our fans and like-minded musicians around us really care.

So, along with our community and any legends who want to join in, we are going to:

  • Plant 10,000 trees in the UK
  • Increase climate change education, without boring people to death.
  • De-bunk the bullshit, at every opportunity

 

WHAT WE DOING AND WHEN

The first planting mission (virus permitting) is one weekend day in mid-October 2020 - when we will plant a minimum of 1,000 trees with approx 20-25 volunteers. 

We will plant oak trees, which allow a stable base for a forest to thrive with other species and animals, tailored to the secret planting location just outside London. We are planting with 'Gone West' - who will ensure the trees are maintained and protected for a minimum 99 years - so you KNOW that carbon will be offset with your help here. They will also give us the vital lessons needed to plant trees, so its also going to be a good learning curve if you join us!

The day will consist of digging, trees, hip-hop, great food and some drinks - if doing this isn’t fun, then it’s not worth it (It really is, but you get the gist!)

It's easy to get involved: You can get all sorts of other sneaky treats in the Perks section on the right over there ---->

And remember the more we raise the more trees we plant, there is no upper limit to what we can do and we can plant more or all of the 10,000 overall target on the first trip! Please help us do the undebatable right thing for the planet here.

 

WHAT WE NEED MONEY FOR

  • Oak tree saplings 
  • Guard tubes and stake
  • Contribution to IndieGoGo costs

AND

  • Help spreading the word, share this campaign and the music video
  • Help us build a community of like-minded people :)

Notes...

- Each tree planter will be responsible for travel costs to destination, we will help organise car shares.

- We will ask people to bring some shareable food for the group.

- We will ask people to bring tools if they have some, but our planting partners will help with equipment too. 

- We are all donating 15 signed copies of our LA FAM ILL vinyl for sale and all will contribute to trees going in the ground.

- We will be back with another fundraise to plant more towards the target in 2021!

----------------

Who are Too Many T’s

Leon & Ross - are an award-winning, fun-loving rap duo who have toured the world performing their unique brand of infectious high-energy-feel-good hip hop.

Following the successful campaign to raise money to provide hives for 60,000 new bees they are once again switching lanes and shifting focus towards their passion for environmental issues. With your support they are hoping to reduce carbon emissions and use our platform to catalyse real change.

TMT's say... “We aim to make people feel good, but we also really care about the state of the earth and have to speak up and take action in whatever way we can. Trying to combine this positive vibe while highlighting the plight of the earth is not an easy task, but we’ve tried to do that with this project.”

“Launching the track reminds us that there are still many serious issues we are facing, both nationally and globally, and we offer some direct action with Too Many Trees - something we hope will snowball over the years into a huge project.”

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - 

So let's do this people!

Any support you can offer us will be much appreciated.

Donate as generously as you can. 

And share the Campaign - let people know whats going on - https://igg.me/at/toomanytrees

 

See FAQ for more info and please ask us any questions. If you have land for future planting missions, then please get in touch: info@toomanyts.com

story:
Sport Kitchen – help us become no-plastic fantastic!

Over the past ten years, we here at Sport Kitchen have been helping some of the nation’s top athletes with their nutrition. We have customers that include medal winning athletes, international and national football/rugby clubs and many other professional sport teams. We have quite a CV!

We’re also heavily involved with gyms, retail stores and people who are conscious of their health. Our innovative brand of freeze-dried food, both main meals and desserts, is not only yummy and convenient but good for you, a great combination.

But one thing has niggled us. Our packaging.

 
 

Sport Kitchen ‘Team Gaffer’ Gareth Wotton explained. “Although we use 95% recyclable plastic, we would rather not. It doesn’t sit comfortably with our ethos, and with the recent news that a massive eight million pieces of plastic enter the world’s oceans every day, it’s time for action. The “UK Plastics Pact”, signed in April 2018, saw the big businesses agree to aim to stop using single-use plastics by 2025, a worthy target but a very distant one. That’s an awful lot of days at 8 million items per day.”

So here at Sport Kitchen, we’ve vowed to make the change, and make it now. But we need some help along the way, and that’s where you come in. We have the necessary funds to commission the machinery required to go green but, need to raise £20,000 in order to buy the volume of packaging materials to help us eradicate the plastic and bring in something far more eco-friendly. The big boys have the resources to do this, but we have just our heart, our vision and our energy so we need your help in this.
 

Remember the song, “It Isn’t Easy Being Green”? Correct, it’s not, but it’s the right thing to do. But once we’ve switched, our costs will be lowered, and we can pass this on to you, the customer; you, the athlete; you, the club.

By donating to the campaign, you’ll be helping us help the planet. We’ll give everyone that donates either exclusive products or discounts as a thank you, without you giving us a push, our journey will be that much longer. Your pledge will give us the edge!
 

Sport kitchen has always supported sport from the grassroots to individuals and squads, being too small to compete with multinationals we have achieved this through a supported sport program of generous discounts to worthy causes.

WHAT THE MONEY WILL BE SPENT ON

If you can pledge towards our campaign, we will use the money to buy the packaging we need to convert all our products to the eco-friendly / bio-degradable packaging.

The suppliers of such packaging have large MOQ’s (minimum order quantities), not only that but they have large MOQ’s per flavour. We have 15 flavours, so this means a big outlay on packaging, hence we are seeking the funding.

This is why we see the switch to eco-friendly packaging as aimed at the ‘big boys’ of business, the ‘corporate giants’, as there is little flexibility on MOQ’s which means a lot of smaller companies starting are out are forced down packaging routes such as plastic. 

Because this packaging needs specific sealing etc….

We are funding the machinery costs ourselves, so we’re making a big investment in this ourselves.

We would just love your help on raising this £20,000 for the packaging.

WHAT WILL HAPPEN IF WE’RE OVERFUNDED

If this campaign goes overfunded, we will do something that we’ve done before but on a larger scale!

In bad weather and similar situations, we’ve often taken meals to local homeless charities to help distribute free meals to the homeless. We’ll use any overfunding to carry this on, on a much bigger scale. We’ll post updates on this page if that happens. 

We will also expand our Vegetarian and Vegan range, we always have lot’s of unique products and flavours in mind, so overfunding will help us to put these products to market quicker.

RISKS & CHALLENGES

This campaign holds very little risks. 

We’re an established, small, niche market business of 10 years, we have lots of routes to market globally and we know that this packaging switch is not only right for the environment but right for our customers. 

In terms of challenges, we will have a short transitional period when we switch to the new using machinery and using the new packaging, but once everything is set up and our production staff are ‘au fait’ with the operational side of things we will be able to produce a vast number of products daily. 

NON-ENVIRONMENTAL BENEFITS

You will have a good idea of the environmental benefits of this campaign, but here are few other good reasons to make the switch:

Productivity will be far greater and more efficient 

Much larger appeal meaning greater revenue opportunities

More opportunities to help the homeless, schools, and grassroots sports clubs

New jobs will be created and there will be greater job security for the current team

We are just about to invest £30,000 ourselves for machinery to automate our production line, so the two changes at the same time will be such a huge leap forward for the business

Aside from the pledges you can see listed on this campaign, we also have some other great opportunities for retailers and distributors globally! 

PLASTIC / TRASH DID YOU KNOW:

At least 8million pieces of plastic are entering oceans every day

2/3 of this is from land-based sources

Plastic bottles can last 450 years in the marine environment

Wildlife can be entangled or think it’s food 

Humans can then eat fish which has eaten plastic

100k marine mammals and turtles and 1 million sea birds are killed by marine plastic pollution annually

We’re looking for retailers/distributors in the following countries/regions:

UK
Scandinavia
France 
Italy
Germany
Asia Pacific
North America (Joint venture/manufacturing partner)

We can offer bespoke flavours for your country, co-branded labelling and label translation. 

For more information please contact us – trade@sportkitchen.com

story:
What is Relief4Sandy?

#Relief4Sandy is a movement dedicated to the relief of those affected by Hurricane Sandy that occurred in late October 2012. Hurricane Sandy struck the Northeastern Coast, Mid-Atlantic and some parts of the Caribbean which caused the loss of homes, power, heat, well being, memories, and normal way of life. This movement is a united effort with those from all parts of the world who want to be active and involved.

We are using indiegogo.com to raise funds which will be donated to the American Red Cross and another organization, that is undetermined at the moment, for those who were affected. We will help by working with others, using social media, and implementing conservative fund raising methods. #Relief4Sandy is working hard to make a difference and help change people’s lives for the better.

How can you help?

We need YOU to make a difference and help. Here are 3-steps on how YOU can get involved.

Step 1. Email us at Relief4Sandy@gmail.com with a photo and/or video of your experience of Hurricane Sandy in your immediate area. A picture/video can be of any damage, long gas lines, floods, or anything you had witnessed during/after Hurricane Sandy. The picture/video will be posted on our blog to help spread awareness.

Step 2. Join the movement by visiting our Indiegogo page. By donating the minimum of $10 you will receive a #Relief4Sandy wristband. Donations of $25 or more there will be other incentives to show our appreciation.

Step 3. Spread the News! Relief and awareness of Hurricane Sandy is not over and there are victims that still need our help. You can continue to be involved by spreading the Hashtag #Relief4Sandy on your social media post(s) through Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, and Tumblr. Like us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/Relief4Sandy  and follow us on twitter: @BxCStudios

 SPONSORED BY B&C STUDIOS. WWW.BXCSTUDIOS.COM

story:
Who we are

Pentagono design is an international team of 5 Master students at the Industrial Design & Engineering faculty at the Technical University of Delft. Catalina from Colombia and Irene from Italy are strategic product designers, Olaf and Jaco from The Netherlands are integrated product designers, and Paul from Taiwan is an interaction designer. Our team was created in June 2012 to conduct the Joint Master Project with a common goal: use our capabilities to design for a Base Of the Pyramid context with human centred design and participatory design as key drivers to develop actionable and meaningful solutions.

What is the project about?

Currently in Sulawesi, Indonesia an NGO led by Willie Smits named the Masarang Foundation is working together with the local community to preserve the rainforest and reforest pieces of land of which some, especially in Kalimantan, are degraded by the palm oil industry. They do this by exploiting a palm tree called the ‘sugar palm’ that can only live in a mixed forest. This palm tree delivers sugar juice on a daily basis that is processed into sugar and sold by Masarang. The selling of the sugar provides income for the local community. The local community knows that their source of income, the sugar palm, is dependent on the mixed forest so they protect this forest against illegal loggers and the palm oil industry. Masarang also uses the money earned with the sugar for reforestation programs and community development.

Masarang designed a smaller version of the Tomohon factory called the ‘village hub’. Their goal is to install these village hubs in multiple parts of Indonesia where the land has been degraded by the palm oil industry. The land will be reforested and the sugar palm trees will be planted to create income for the local people. The success of this goal depends on the willingness of the local people to adapt the sugar palm as their source of income and become ‘sugar palm farmers’. Increasing the value of the sugar palm for the local people can enhance their willingness to use it in a sustainable way, therefore contributing with the reforestation of Indonesia. Within this perspective, Masarang sees potential in other commodities from the sugar palm, such as the sugar palm fruit that is currently not being used.

Our project assignment is to develop a product with the sugar palm fruit as a basis in order to increase the value of the sugar palm for the villagers. We will first research the possibilities of the fruit. What can we make out of it? A food product, or maybe a beauty product? Then we will perform a market research. Should we sell it in Indonesia? Or is it better to ship it to the Netherlands and sell it here? With this knowledge we will design the product and its business model.
 
We will also need to design the production process. The product should be produced by local people using local resources and use as little energy as possible. This includes the design of production tools (e.g. for harvesting, transporting or cooking the fruit) and clear instructions for implementation.

Click here for a TED talk of Willie Smits on how to restore a rainforest

Click here to read about Masarang foundation and its current projects

Click here for more information about the sugar palm and the Village hubs

Why design research?

Our approach is build on the basis that research should inform and inspire our design and development process. Human centered design aims to understand the context and relations where the product or service interacts with the users in order to better meet their needs. Furthermore, participatory design (generative design research and co-creation) actively involves people served through the upcoming products or services as experts in the design and development process. Through methods, techniques and tools designed specifically to the context and project characteristics, participatory design gives voice to communities and allows their desires to be the drivers of the design and development of solutions.

Consequently with our approach and project background we are going to Tomohon for two months (February 28 to April 28 2013) to conduct in-context research and design phases of our project. Involving local people in the design process not only ensures meaningful solutions but also increases their engagement with the upcoming project testing and implementation phases.

Participatory design techniques and tools are empathic techniques that motivate non-designers to participate in different activities for specific parts of the design process. Furthermore, this approach helps to lower language and communication barriers between the design team, the local community and other project stakeholders. A human centered design mindset will allow us to dive deep into the local culture, share knowledge and underpin opportunities for meaningful solutions.

For more information about design-led research techniques visit:

Am I A designer

HCD connect

How can you help us?

We are highly motivated and ready to start this project. We have been working and preparing ourselves to carry out an insightful research in the real context. However we need your support to make this happen.

Local research not only implies our transportation from The Netherlands to Indonesia but also the creation of research materials, local expenses and prototyping of the product and production tools. For this we need financial support. We will appreciate your collaboration. We ask you to donate from 5 to 500 euro and be part of this challenge to protect the rainforest in Indonesia.

We believe that learning from local people and diving deep into their environment will ensure a successful project development, will contribute to the overall goal of reforestation in Indonesia and will enrich our professional and personal experience.

How can you follow this journey?

Visit our webpage www.pentagonodesign.com

We will keep you updated about the project progress, daily news and visual inspiration about our experience throughout this journey.

As a donor we will keep you informed about the design and development process and how your contribution will be used in this process. Our webpage is being already promoted under TU Delft students among other important networks.

Thank you for being part and supporting us in this meaningful experience :)
story_txt:
Who we are
Pentagono design is an international team of 5 Master students at the Industrial Design & Engineering faculty at the Technical University of Delft. Catalina from Colombia and Irene from Italy are strategic product designers, Olaf and Jaco from The Netherlands are integrated product designers, and Paul from Taiwan is an interaction designer. Our team was created in June 2012 to conduct the Joint Master Project with a common goal: use our capabilities to design for a Base Of the Pyramid context with human centred design and participatory design as key drivers to develop actionable and meaningful solutions.

story:
Short Summary

A new independent journalism movement

  • Support the freedom of press and jounalism !
  • Protect the truth about the fukushima daichi power plant catastrophe!
  • Help to educate the Billions of people affected by the tripple nuclear meltdown!

What We Need & What You Get

We need money for cameras, transportation, computers, archive backup, networking.

With funding we will provide breakings news current events, reports, footage, and any available information to the general public

Any ammount of funding raised will be used to purchase the necessities of jounalism and reporting for volounteer independent journalist. 

The Impact

What happens when the money trail leads back to you

  • Aren't you tired of relying on biased reporting and propaganda
  • With crowd funded reporting there are no hidden agendas or loyalties
  • The proffit:people equation is balanced and truth can prevail, making the pen once again mightier than the sword.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about what you learn.
  • Encourage others to use independent sources of journalism!
  • Get out of your cave, and don't get sucked back in!
